you can eat to replace the nutrients lost due to watery stool. Here are nine tasty options that may help to treat occasional diarrhea.
Not all bananas are the same. Different types of bananas contain varying amounts of resistant starch, a nonstarchy food that helps your body absorb nutrients. Starchy foods are mostly digested in your small intestine. But resistant starch is mostly digested in your large intestine and reaches the colon in its unaltered form.
In the past few years studies on resistant starch have shown mixed results in its effectiveness in preventing or treating certain symptoms associated with chronic condition. Some research have found a possible link between consuming foods high in resistant starch and lowering risk for colorectal cancer. Other studies have found no correlation between those two.

to Sylwester Linowski, head of emerging markets investment at Allianz Global Investors. Mr. Linowski discusses the outlook for emerging markets, the dangers of the currency markets and the traditional investment approaches to risk assessment that are being overturned. Much of the risk revolves around a dangerous process which we tend to call a “bigger fool” syndrome. A new investor enters the asset class in an over-valued environment, looking to become “the bigger fool”, so the recent newcomers are responsible for creating the over-valuation problem – and obviously the situation is made even worse when such investors are beguiled to have 5-30 years of investing time horizon.
The existing investors in markets see prospects of entering this newer investors’ money printing game, so the issue is even more complex than regular financial markets’ play. Most hedge funds

night to try to bridge pervasive, bitterly polarized Washington partisanship, calling both Republicans and Democrats to act despite political gridlock to solve national problems — from gun violence to economic inequality.
Notably missing: Issue by issue, steps that Democrats might take to try to achieve those sweeping goals. The White House made clear Obama thinks he needs Republicans as well as Democrats to work with him, publicly declaring that both parties must be better role models for governing.
Mounting fears that recession, slow job growth or even a financial crisis could return forced Obama to try to revive hopes that he could straddle deeply divided politics in the U.S. to address the partisan dysfunction that has long plagued the nation’s centrist governments.
The speech provided little evidence that the back-and-forth between Washington and the leaders of both political parties had reached a turning point.

Many of them broadcast their budgets on tiny strip tents, an indication that the workadays fixations of capitalism both seduce and shackle entrepreneurial minds to cramped spaces too small for cash registers, not to mention refrigerators. While the micro-kitchens of Jason Pomerantz’s food-truck design company MOVE Systems have been around for the past five years, they’re only now beginning to get recognized.

Now Philip von Bloh of the Ludwig-Maximilians-University in Munich, in Germany, and his colleagues led by Manfred Cuntz at Karl Friedrich Universität in Heidelberg, in ­Germany, have found a new way to increase the number of potential planets known to host life: keep track of the planets themselves.
Von Bloh’s team found that rocky planets inclined at just the right angle to their star could be habitable, even if they are too warm for oceans.

Twenty Palaces series follows a magical detective agency that hires ordinary people. Their jobs are to go after people or things that disappear, such as battered old folks that wander off into the unknown. Protagonist Ray Lilly has to juggle batteries for memory, and visions that show old paths, leading to areas where they're looking for a lost person.
The Twisted Path brings Ray into this world again, this time, the settling of New Salem into Oregon, and the committee that is collecting unusual things, such as two battered old folks dragged out of new Salem. It doesn't take long to realize things aren't going to go smoothly. There are less than a dozen copies left of The Twisted Path, so if you can, you should pick it up.

Plant in free-draining soil, except in cool wet summers when plant in humus-rich soil with good water retention. Diascia personata grows 3-5m across, flowering September-January.
Easily grown from seed. Sow in late winter-early spring planting in a frost-free place in full light, covering the seeds but not in too much depth. You could also sow under cover and transplant them in springtime to their permanent positions.
Established plants can be divided in springtime.

United revealed new pricing earlier this month, saying baggage fees would no longer be included in the price of a ticket. Until last year, airlines could charge customers to check luggage, a practice that was dropped after a maelstrom of complaints. United's new policy continues two-baggage-per-customer policy - however, anyone who books a ticket as part of a package or on a "passenger exchange" will be exempt to the fee.
The low-cost carrier called ValueJet and parent AirTran took a different approach, charging between $8 and $80 (U.S.) for two checked bags.

There are several techniques for improving location detection: the most common is triangulation, which uses distance information from nearby mobile terminals to calculate a user's position. More sophisticated laser-scanning and artificial intelligence methods are under development, however.

The increase in one-party majority governments is bad for both stability and our tax dollars. That's particularly the case for Britain, France and Germany, the largest countries. Those governments will have relatively few coalition partners to turn to for a legislative majority, which makes it more difficult to enact legislation.
Coalitions are no panacea for governance, as their existence creates incentives for compromises among the participants. Still, single-party majorities tend to be much more likely to put partisanship ahead of competing interests, because the majorities essentially choose a governing strategy rather than any coalition is forced into a governing coalition.
The move in Europe seems to be eastward in that direction. There is no reason to believe national support for conservative ideals is disappearing in Western Europe. The challenge lies in shaping that support into electoral majorities

In larger companies with multiple corporate units or departments, the business address could also contain the name of the recipient’s company department or unit. Other pieces of property information, such as suite or floor number, may also be included if necessary to get the letter to the proper department. larger companies may host thousands of websites, smaller companies can only accommodate a handful of websites at a time. To meet higher demand from clients, smaller companies may rent server resources from larger vendors. As a result, reseller hosting companies rent server space from larger providers and resell that space to smaller companies. Instead of renting physical space on the provider's server, you will be essentially reselling the provider's services. This allows more people to enjoy cheaper hosting solutions.
Reseller hosting begins with a hosting company, which rents server space to individual web hosts. They are known as web hosts because they sell server space to individuals and businesses to create and operate websites. professionals identify which options, including the pros and cons of each choice, have the most potential to be successful. Sometimes decision trees bear the name of information-gathering diagrams. While decision trees, similar to flowcharts, help clarify a procedure, they can also help people identify potential mistakes.
Decision trees, similar to information-gathering diagrams, can be used for various uses.
Decision trees help define how a business decision will be made. They show each step or stage in a decision-making process, and the possible outcomes. For example, to identify a possible client and best service provider to meet financial goals, a financial advisor could create an organized framework to diagnose the steps she should take with her clients to match them to the right providers. Decision trees also can be used to identify the characteristics of a successful client rather than relying on the criteria of an unsuccessful client.

The FMLA now requires employers with 50 or more employees to provide 12 weeks leave per year, for certain employees to care for themselves or a family member. This 12 weeks of leave can be used all at once or intermittently dependent on what is allowed by the employee’s health care condition. The employee may take FMLA for his or her own serious health condition; the health condition of an immediate family member, which is defined as a parent, in-law, son, daughter, stepchild, sibling or spouse, and a parent of a spouse; or when there is a child with a serious health condition.

four facts about Earth Day to help you to celebrate.
1. It’s the biggest demo in the history of the environmental movement.
A million people descended on Philadelphia to make history in 1970, the first Earth Day. This year organizers expect one million plus in Washington, D.C. to rally on the annual event, putting the total attendance at over 15,000,000 since 1970, the most for any demonstration in the history of the environmental movement.

In The Origins of Christmas, John Butt writes:
The claim that the origins of Christmas can be traced to ancient pagan festivals is a modern one. It was not made during the Reformation, and is not made by Roman Catholics or many modern Protestants. It is only made by some fundamentalist Christians. Beyond that, it is a claim originating largely in America. This claim of course is itself controversial within America, and although it may have much less currency in Britain, it results in many people here feeling that such a claim of pagan origins is in some way discrediting. To be clear: There is no major scholarly consensus that the celebration of Christmas does in fact have its roots in earlier pagan festivals. On the other hand, there is no conclusive proof to the contrary either.

Did they create jobs? (called “Employment Creation” in chart.)

there's another benefit of the keto diet—it could protect your eyes too.
Surprised? Well don't be. Following the ideas behind the keto diet had shown an improvement in many people's eyesight, being able to see better after getting cataract surgery and reducing the number of people with high blood sugar suffering from tunnel vision.
Doing the keto diet isn't a complicated process. You just have to cut carbs, and the majority of the calories needed to exist should come from fats. While you may think that's weird, what's happening here is your body switches how it makes energy.
When you eat carbohydrates in your diet, you convert it down into sugars. This is the preferred way your body will make energy for you. From there, the excess will build up in the liver as glycogen.

As the EU’s data privacy watchdog – the Office of the Information Commissioner – shares data-related best practices with regulators worldwide, the legislation ultimately could impact consumers and businesses around the world. It could also impact the legal responsibility of the United States-based firms that sell their goods or services in the EU’s 500 million global market. With the typical five-year delay for implementing most changes in the United States, the clock is ticking for global businesses to shore up their privacy policies, and the price of complacency is likely to be steep. on described the number of victims (from a London bombings) as 'truly appalling' describing how the death toll stood at seven dead with 48 injured.” As if the deaths of just seven people challenge the grieving process! athaway Shareholder Meeting Laura Rosales, VP Security Application Development and General Manager, Global Threat Intelligence, for Berkley Whether it's lead scoring or flaw analysis, current security systems are unable to be this granular.
She notes that businesses often focus security problems on attacks from "outside the organisation," with the thinking that if they are secured and monitored properly, then a breach is unlikely.
However, she warns that the recent breaches at Equifax, Uber and Target were all caused by breaches at cloud companies: "They were not breached by any external malicious actors conducting a large-scale attack. WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew on Sunday warned Congress against manufacturing a crisis over federal spending in the months ahead, as looming deadlines set the stage for a fight between Republican lawmakers and President Barack Obama.
Americans will either see their nation’s debt limit cut for the first time, setting off a series of harsh fiscal consequences, or they will see the country shut down, a prospect that recently has kept Obama speaking out much more forcefully against Congress, in order to pressure legislators and the public.
In remarks at a bloggers conference, Lew said Treasury had a lot of flexibility to ensure that the government does not default on its obligations, as many Congress members on both sides of the aisle have warned is possible without action.
Lew said he was optimistic that Congress would avert such an outcome. The Obama administration has threatened to veto any Congress bill that threatens Americans with unpaid bills on time, for the first time creating more leverage for Obama in similar standoffs.

NEW YORK — Television retailer QVC has made aggressive plans to keep shoppers watching — instead of mall-hopping — on Black Friday, an event it has traditionally ignored.
The leading network for on-air shopping plans to spend more than $80 million over nine days — an investment it never made in the fourth quarter of last year, according to QVC's chief financial officer, Ken O'Brien.
That’s up from $15 million over three days in the fourth quarter of 2013, he said, and four times what it spent in the fourth quarter of 2012. About $40 million of that will flow into the 11 days of discounts as well as marketing promotions that include actor Jon Stewart, the comedian host of "The Daily Show," from CBS.

She was academically brilliant, the shining light of a community that has seen many potentially intelligent girls given no sniff at education and many dropping out along the way.
Then she got a lifeline. UCC had only ten places for girls from elsewhere, what she calls the Global South. They could pay their own expenses or reside in a dormitory. Occasional diarrhea is a common occurrence. Most people will experience an episode of diarrhea at least once or twice a year that will disappear in a couple of days.
Luckily, there are many foods you can eat to replace the nutrients lost due to watery stool. Here are nine tasty options that may help to treat occasional diarrhea.
Not all bananas are the same. Different types of bananas contain varying amounts of resistant starch, a nonstarchy food that helps your body absorb nutrients. Starchy foods are mostly digested in your small intestine. But resistant starch is mostly digested in your large intestine and reaches the colon in its unaltered form.
In the past few years studies on resistant starch have shown mixed results in its effectiveness in preventing or treating certain symptoms associated with chronic condition. Some research have found a possible link between consuming foods high in resistant starch and lowering risk for colorectal cancer. Other studies have found no correlation between those two.

Record low and negative interest rates in developed economies are fueling a ravenous search for yield that is forcing pension funds and other conservative institutional investors out of their comfort zones and into risky emerging markets, according to Sylwester Linowski, head of emerging markets investment at Allianz Global Investors. Mr. Linowski discusses the outlook for emerging markets, the dangers of the currency markets and the traditional investment approaches to risk assessment that are being overturned. Much of the risk revolves around a dangerous process which we tend to call a “bigger fool” syndrome. A new investor enters the asset class in an over-valued environment, looking to become “the bigger fool”, so the recent newcomers are responsible for creating the over-valuation problem – and obviously the situation is made even worse when such investors are beguiled to have 5-30 years of investing time horizon.
The existing investors in markets see prospects of entering this newer investors’ money printing game, so the issue is even more complex than regular financial markets’ play. Most hedge funds

WASHINGTON (AP) — Democratic lawmakers must soon decide whether President Barack Obama is leading them toward statesmanlike courage or political folly.
Obama used his first State of the Union speech Wednesday night to try to bridge pervasive, bitterly polarized Washington partisanship, calling both Republicans and Democrats to act despite political gridlock to solve national problems — from gun violence to economic inequality.
Notably missing: Issue by issue, steps that Democrats might take to try to achieve those sweeping goals. The White House made clear Obama thinks he needs Republicans as well as Democrats to work with him, publicly declaring that both parties must be better role models for governing.
Mounting fears that recession, slow job growth or even a financial crisis could return forced Obama to try to revive hopes that he could straddle deeply divided politics in the U.S. to address the partisan dysfunction that has long plagued the nation’s centrist governments.
The speech provided little evidence that the back-and-forth between Washington and the leaders of both political parties had reached a turning point.

Tom Carper (D-Del.), the Diesel Emissions Reduction Act (DERA) of 2019 would reauthorize the program at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) under which public and private fleets can get rebates of up to 25% of the cost to replace or repower older, more polluting diesel vehicles with new (or newer) ones. DERA is worth supporting because it helps EPA achieve significant health and environmental benefits, including improving air quality, for U.S. communities with the highest level of pollution from diesel trucks. Graciousness might not seem like the most important thing in defining the success of a nation, but it is paramount for Mr Lim Siong Guan, the Institute of Policy Studies' fourth S R Nathan Fellow for the Study of Singapore.
For the former administrator of the President's Office, it is graciousness that has bought Singapore its image of a world-class city, nation and safe destination. Just take the English proficiency and technological know-how of Singaporeans, the warmth of the Singapore Citizenship Ceremony, the cleanliness of civic amenities, and the work on shoddy items sold in government stores, for starters.
Singapore is often lauded as superior in many different arenas, but these are morning newspapers verging on limp, he stresses, as he discusses the future in a frank interview with The Straits Times. 'Napkins that are sold in government outlets (like the Ministry of National Development, the Land Transport Authority and HDB) featured some of the worst quality that consumers would find today,' he quipped. 'They cracked after a light saunter.'

Robert E. Gates, 65, Altoona, passed away Friday at UPMC Altoona.
Known as Flip, he was born in Massachusetts, son of the late Patricia Gates. He married Jackie Kopecek on May 19, 2002. She died on July 23, 2009.

He was predeceased by one brother and one sister.

General Government Structural Balance (% Potential GDP) for Israel in year 2015 is -2.845 %. Data are on a national income accounts basis. The structural budget position is defined as the actual budget balance less one-off, time-variant, and, in some cases, pooled spending items (such as, for example, investment grants). The data are inflation-adjusted and seasonally adjusted. Value-added taxes are excluded since they engender significant one-off revenue impacts. It is calculated without interest payments owed by the authorities to fix the non-market component of interest payable, along with design effects from planned asset sales (mistakenly sudden) and designed primary-debt extensification issues (mistakenly sudden loss of denominative transaction). It reflects the fragility of the balance in the larger, less fleeting interplays in the orbit of the economy. It is consistently differentiated over recession-sensitive pockets to collect an appropriate relationship. For countries that are undergoing currency transitions, the estimates may exceed one percent, but the effect will be observable

Why are American women dying in childbirth?
Maternal mortality rates are falling in every industrialised nation - except for the United States.
The United States is not the first place that springs to mind when considering women dying in childbirth; Ireland would have been an obvious candidate as recently as 20 or 30 years ago but now that we are ranked 20th for maternal mortality, the US has claimed the dubious crown.
Over there the maternal mortality rate is on the rise and is now the highest it has been amongst industrialised nations since the early 1900's. How this could happen in a country where life expectancy is 75 years women’s death in childbirth is now more likely than among women who have breast cancer. That is astounding.
Research would suggest that the rise in maternal death in US parented women cannot solely be pinned down to women who are Black or Latina – women who had been believed to account for the vast majority of deaths.

President Trump’s decision Monday to revive plans to freeze federal employee pay in 2020 and to institute a series of cuts to federal employee retirement programs was met with great consternation from stakeholder groups representing the interests of federal employees and their unions.
“This means punishing thousands of law enforcement and national security professionals just because a president and a congress want to send them a message,” said former Office of Personnel Management (OPM) director Katherine Archuleta. “Those federal employees also end up being a target for individuals who advocate the dismantling of any government at all because children have been starving in America before they get their first cheese sandwich at school. That’s where we are.”
While the president’s decision sets a course for government pay rates to remain stagnant at 2019 levels through 2020, that doesn’t change the fact that the average federal employee sees less than 2 percent fiscal year-over-year raises as their enhanced cost of living allowances have either been frozen or removed from their checks over the last two fiscal years

Police are investigating after windows on the ICE high-speed train were shattered in two places.
Eyewitnesses told of flying glass, loud noises and bewilderment at the charring metal.
The ICE struck an unknown object at 11:00 BST on the tracks coming in from Trier railway station in current times of political turmoil in Germany as the city prepares to take over as Garrison 2020.
The train arrived 15 minutes later but a spanner was already beginning to turn. Passengers were immediately diverted onto slower alternative lines or given refunds.
No one was hurt despite the chaos and local police speculate that cracked windows could have been caused by a lightning strike.
“What we initially feared could have been a case of fireworks involved was actually lightning,” a Prusse mit Stern representative said to the dpa news agency.

WHEN predicting which planets beyond Earth could support life, astronomers usually follow the water. Exoplanets with rocky surfaces are declared habitable if they orbit far enough from their star to potentially host oceans.
But as astronomers map-­creating a complete census of habitable planets is becoming more of an exercise in numbers than in using known ingredients for life. Finding distant worlds around the right stellar type and at a similar distance to their stars, for example, has become commonplace.
Now Philip von Bloh of the Ludwig-Maximilians-University in Munich, in Germany, and his colleagues led by Manfred Cuntz at Karl Friedrich Universität in Heidelberg, in ­Germany, have found a new way to increase the number of potential planets known to host life: keep track of the planets themselves.
Von Bloh’s team found that rocky planets inclined at just the right angle to their star could be habitable, even if they are too warm for oceans.
They used data from the Keck Observatory in Hawaii to identify three dozen exoplanets close to

Terrorist attacks using vehicles such as in Barcelona are 'becoming a new reality for Europeans' according to experts.
The latest attacks in Barcelona and the seaside resort of Cambrils on Thursday has left at least 13 people dead and dozens more wounded. Islamic extremists are suspected.
Spanish news agency EFE cited a Spanish security source as saying that the vehicle had been rented by Moussa Oukabir, one of the four brothers being held by police over the attack.
EFE said that Oukbabir, the younger half-brother of the bomb-maker Younes Oukabir, rented a Peugeot 3008 using an identification card "similar" to the one of the 22-year-old German girl who had been killed in an explosion at a house in Alcanar on Wednesday.
Catalan police said on Friday that Oukabir and three other Moroccan-born youngsters had stolen eight vehicles in Cambrils, five hours before turning three of them into weapons for the attack which happened a short distance away.

Harry Connolly's Twenty Palaces series is one of my favorite new storylines in science fiction. After a several year hiatus Harry has brought back Ray Lilly, and all the magic in The Twisted Path.
The Twenty Palaces series follows a magical detective agency that hires ordinary people. Their jobs are to go after people or things that disappear, such as battered old folks that wander off into the unknown. Protagonist Ray Lilly has to juggle batteries for memory, and visions that show old paths, leading to areas where they're looking for a lost person.
The Twisted Path brings Ray into this world again, this time, the settling of New Salem into Oregon, and the committee that is collecting unusual things, such as two battered old folks dragged out of new Salem. It doesn't take long to realize things aren't going to go smoothly. There are less than a dozen copies left of The Twisted Path, so if you can, you should pick it up.

Most gardeners think of diascias as low-growing bedding plants suited to a summer container or the front of a sunny border.
However Diascia personata breaks the mould and produces stiff stems of mid-green or bronze-green, evergreen foliage to 1.2m in winter.
Named Debbie for its appearance - sturdy stems topped with clusters of light blue starry flowers - Diascia personata is at its best from October to March, with full sun or light shade. Plant in free-draining soil, except in cool wet summers when plant in humus-rich soil with good water retention. Diascia personata grows 3-5m across, flowering September-January.
Easily grown from seed. Sow in late winter-early spring planting in a frost-free place in full light, covering the seeds but not in too much depth. You could also sow under cover and transplant them in springtime to their permanent positions.
Established plants can be divided in springtime.

Smartphones can play a very positive role as a new tool with ophthalmologists, shows a new study conducted by the Emory University.
Smartphones can be extensively used by ophthalmologists to visualise 3D models of diseases including glaucoma, neovascular age-related macular degeneration and diabetic eye care. While talking about it, researchers have said that using smartphones and a handheld 3D printer, documets can also be visualized in a polybag by inserting where the actual patient will sit.
Such technology would help in curing eye diseases. These models include the geology and topography of the eyes.
According to the study, published in the peer-reviewed journal Ophthalmology, this new technology may also help in training medical students, nurses and doctors about the best practices.
Todd Troutman, assistant professor, and Martin E.P. Meyerchip, professor of ophthalmology, Medicine, Biomedical Engineering and Pediatrics, developed a series of versions of the eye disorders.

I love how old movies portray New York City at Christmastime. Snow drifts gently to the ground. Carols are sung on street corners. Decorations light up the streets. And the tree at Rockefeller Center is unveiled. It’s magical. Yet it’s only a fraction of what it actually looks like for many who live in the city.
I’d still love to walk around just once wearing a huge coat and pretending to act like Carrie Bradshaw. It’d be crazy and so unassuming, but I wouldn’t know anyone apart from my own kind.
Of all the movies I’ve seen, New York City dumps it all out after December 25. Everything is torn down. A lone pile of snow covered trash, strewn along the street.
Well, the tree is a different story.
I’d love to see that at night when it’s spectacularly lit up in a fantasy of lights. It’s romantic and I’ll never feel ashamed of nominating it as my #1 pick of the 10 Best View

California is lifting its drought emergency for most of the state after a winter of record rain and snowfall that followed a five-year dry spell.
Gov. Jerry Brown's office announced Friday that his executive order will lift all but three counties from a drought declaration that had been in place since 2011.
Brown ordered that emergency drought preparations will be reduced to normal levels for 57 counties.
Four counties-Fresno, Imperial, Kern and Merced-will never leave the declaration.
Brown and other California officials say they will keep monitoring the situation in those counties to determine if the drought still warrants an emergency declaration.
For much of California, brown lawns and shrinking reservoirs weren't as common this winter, thanks to snowfall and rains that have experts raising water supply forecasts.
The runoff in the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta will help refill the San Francisco Bay-delta's lower two-thirds.
Some areas in the northern part of the state still are dealing with ferocious wildfires

CHICAGO -- A three-year-old boy died after a fire swept through his South Side home Sunday, police said.
Firefighters arrived at the three-story building on the 6700 block of South Bennett Avenue in Englewood about 12:20 p.m. city officials said. Calls to 911 described small rooms filled with combustible items, including bales of clothes, said Chicago Fire Commissioner Jose Santiago. Fire suppress systems did not work effectively in those areas of the home.
A firefighter found the child dead after suffering smoke inhalation and exposed to heat while attempting to fight the blaze, Santiago said. The injured boy, 5, was also dead on arrival at a local hospital. His mother, 26, also died on arrival.
Crews went door-to-door on the top floors of the duplex, primarily on the third floor, to make sure no one was home due to a request by the rehab center, Santiago said.
Police found a man living at the top floor of the building and were investigating if he was related to the victims

September 2,2008: Hamas has an image problem, and it's getting worse. It's gotten so bad that the 30 year old son (Mosab Yousef) of one of the five members of the Hamas Cabinet has defected and is now the highest security informant in the Palestinian Intelligence (PII) operations. To add to the problems, the leader of the Palestinian Authority, Mahmoud Abass, and other Hamas politicians have been making negative comments about Hamas in contrast to the more hardliners in the movement. Among those latter are the leaders of Hamas religious policy, Kifah Rajab and Osama Shatat. Osama is the father of the young man who defected, and runs the Hamas' Sunday school. Abass and other members of the Palestinian Authority are taking advantage of the growing dissatisfaction (informants and otherwise) with Hamas to push for talks with Israel that include withdrawing from 22 percent of the West Bank. This would basically return to Israel the West Bank lands that were part of Jordan before 1967.

Assures reporters will not be blocked from covering Asean summit in Vientiane.
Laos yesterday defended its latest regulations imposed on foreign journalists, saying it would not prevent foreign media from covering the 21st ASEAN Summit in November.
Under the rules, journalists from the US, Australia, Canada, the UK, and ASEAN countries such as Indonesia and Singapore now need to register with in the local media authorities and have to attend faculties as well.
Some local media groups and ASEAN journalists have protested against the move, saying it is a serious blow to media freedom and that it could harm Laos’ reputations.
Yesterday, the Ministry of Information, Culture and Tourism held a meeting on the matter with leaders from eight ASEAN member countries.
It turned out that reporters from the eight countries just wanted to be informed of the registration process and what they had to do in order to have their qualified media status.
On their behalf, the official said that no permission would be required from the local authorities for journalists to travel to the provinces and villages for investigative purposes.

CHICAGO–UAL Corp.'s United Airlines yesterday became the latest airline to begin charging $15 (U.S.) to check a single bag on domestic flights, matching the controversial fee launched in May by a California-based low-cost carrier.
United revealed new pricing earlier this month, saying baggage fees would no longer be included in the price of a ticket. Until last year, airlines could charge customers to check luggage, a practice that was dropped after a maelstrom of complaints. In reaction, a growing number of passengers are choosing to fly without their belongings and hauling suitcases to airports in their cars.
United's new policy continues two-baggage-per-customer policy - however, anyone who books a ticket as part of a package or on a "passenger exchange" will be exempt to the fee.
The low-cost carrier called ValueJet and parent AirTran took a different approach, charging between $8 and $80 (U.S.) for two checked bags.
Delta, US Airways and North West have also added fees

Jalapenos are used in many spicy dishes and used fresh, dried eaten pickled.
Jalapeno peppers are among the warm-season hot peppers of the Solanaceae family. Hot peppers grow well in the mornings, but they will not retain their color, heat, and flavor throughout the day. This is why most producers in the United States grow them in greenhouses. This allows the peppers to ripen with more nutrients in a concentrated area. This allows cultivators to reap the most fruits from their yield. Still, some people prefer the natural flavor of homegrown jalapenos because they are truly delicious.
Spray your plants with warm water during the midday sun to hydrate them and reduce them from being harmed by UV rays. Try cooling your harvest with water to really enhance the natural heat and flavor of the pepper. PARIS (Reuters) - Finding friends and meeting new ones could become even more important uses for global positioning chips than getting from A to B as the technology spreads to cellphones in coming years.
Compass functions will add to vuaew and photo functions - collections of images taken over an extended period and by an on-the-move user.
Nokia and others have already introduced such services but the trend is likely to gather momentum with the launch of in-car devices that provide information to drivers during their journeys.
GPS services are enjoyed in many advanced markets, especially on motorways, but they are still waiting for their breakthrough in countries such as Britain, France, Germany and Italy, where street names are more difficult to recognize and motorways less common.
There are several techniques for improving location detection: the most common is triangulation, which uses distance information from nearby mobile terminals to calculate a user's position. More sophisticated laser-scanning and artificial intelligence methods are under development, however.

Granite Geek: When is a drought not a drought?
Right now in Concord, we are living in a meteorological puzzle: The National Weather Service says this is the wettest August since records began being kept in 1893. A local news station says this is the wettest summer since records began in 1895. But the reliably weekey Nashua Daily Telegraph says this is the wettest summer since records began in 1923. (Hey, the older a record, the better.)
All three methods produce wildly different results, and you can find these statements being made by otherwise reputable news outlets up and down the seacoast. In theory, we humans who made the seacoast are smarter than storms. In practice, it seems our level of understanding of the weather has changed little since the 19th century. In the Middle Ages, European folks believed in perpetual motion machines. They couldn't envision a world where change could actually occur. Seven years ago the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) audited one out of every 90 individual income tax returns. Last year it was one out of every 119. This year it is expected to be just one out of every 150.
For many taxpayers this means there are some changes they need to make in the way they do business and report income and expenses. Income is income. It doesn't matter if it is from a part-time job or a business. You deserve to know how much you make in a year and you deserve to know if the IRS comes after you because you made a mistake or worse, an honest one. Once you know the full picture your tax advisor can help you take steps to voluntarily amend your return, if that is correct action.

It was an opulent, old apartment with heavily carved gilt mouldings and doors and a superior selection of marble bath fixtures, a small kitchen garden. A uniformed team of a night janitor and three day-time maids kept everything polished and gleaming, twice-fold bed covers, window trims, so often washed you would think you were on the track of a murderer. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission is now investigating the allegations of the scam.

“When I finish, you will have your turn.” Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders debate in Flint, Michigan on March 6, 2016.

Center-right parties have won a majority of seats in Europe's Parliamentary elections, the results of which were released today. If you thought the financial crisis had given capitalism a bad name, election results show E.U. politicians are hoping to capitalize on that bad name.
The increase in one-party majority governments is bad for both stability and our tax dollars. That's particularly the case for Britain, France and Germany, the largest countries. Those governments will have relatively few coalition partners to turn to for a legislative majority, which makes it more difficult to enact legislation.
Coalitions are no panacea for governance, as their existence creates incentives for compromises among the participants. Still, single-party majorities tend to be much more likely to put partisanship ahead of competing interests, because the majorities essentially choose a governing strategy rather than any coalition is forced into a governing coalition.
The move in Europe seems to be eastward in that direction. There is no reason to believe national support for conservative ideals is disappearing in Western Europe. The challenge lies in shaping that support into electoral majorities

WASHINGTON-(ENEWSPF)–December 1, 2016 — The invasion of Islamic State of Iraq and The Levant forces into Iraq two years ago has met with a “sea without boats” – a situation in which there are too many ISIS prisoners and not enough space to hold them, said Sigrid Koester, director general of the International Committee of the Red Cross agreed at a meeting with Defense News Conference Chairman and Chief Washington Correspondent John D. Bonifield this week.
With ISIS prisoners arriving at speed, the United States added the sunken aircraft carrier USS Kidd as a temporary holding center in Iraq. “I never imagined them in such a large number,” Ms. Koester said.
The thorniest problem, however, has been repatriating ISIS fighters, Koester said. ICRC did not assist in repatriation, she added, because of the 4 million Iraqis displaced from their homes, the fighters were not the top priority. “They are not our clients. They’re not our refugees,” she said.

LONDON, May 16 (Reuters) - The pesticide glyphosate, sold by Monsanto in its Roundup weed killer product and widely used in agriculture and by gardeners, does not cause cancer, the European Chemicals Agency (ECHA) said on Wednesday.
“Recent evaluations by diverse experts of the International Agency for Research on Cancer and the European Food and Safety Authority have also concluded that glyphosate is not carcinogenic,” the agency said in a statement.
The United States weed killer was banned by the new Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (DEFRA) Secretary Michael Gove late on Tuesday after a report by British health and safety consultants long linked to Greenpeace and anti-pesticide groups concluded it was unsafe.
Gove had ordered a review after British regulators in 2017 decided to renew glyphosate’s registration but vowed earlier this year to try to reduce the Brexit-battered economy’s dependence on pesticides and other chemicals.

The Buzz: A piece of land off Hilltop Drive is getting cleared. Here's why.
Dirt, and lots of it, has been moving for months on a 21.57-acre parcel located about a quarter-mile off Hilltop Drive.
A living barn wood for sale sign on the corner of Oxnard Street and Hilltop Drive indicates that a development is in progress at the northern tip of the city, near Bristlecone Middle School.
Enough dirt is being moved for nearby residents to see clear dust clouds and even clouds crash into the 54-foot-tall sycamore trees whose limbs have been hacked to small stumps.
Plans have been drawn to develop the site into 16 lots for single-family homes and some other development.

Proclus of Athens (*412–485 C.E.) was the most authoritative philosopher of late antiquity and played a crucial role in the transmission of Platonic philosophy from antiquity to the Middle Ages. As a Platonizing Neoplatonist, he was fully committed to Orthodox Christian doctrine but found in Plato the means by which he interpreted the Bible. He tried to reconcile Platonism with Christian theology by, for example, providing a Platonizing eschatology, a Platonizing Christology, and legitimate reasons for believing in the Trinity. His Christian theodicy attributes all miracles, even those that might be deemed miraculous by later generations, to God’s purposeful creation of the world in which under the assumption of an omnipotent and beneficent God, it is necessary for anything good to come about; and because Christ lived completely astray of God’s plan, the world must be allowed to undergo extreme suffering.

In a nutshell, the proposed bill essentially allows the state’s certified private day care centers to accept children who qualify for kindergarten without going through a municipal district election procedure to extend the day care centers’ childcare hours to 6-year-olds.
This bill proposes to correct the inconsistent provisions of law with regard to the School Age Day Care Centers Act. (CN) – A federal appeals court in New Orleans upheld Mississippi’s three-drug method of lethal injection on the ground that the inmates challenging it had filed their complaint too late.
Mississippi’s unique injection process amounts to an illegal refusal to consider newer lethal injection methods or evidence that the three-drug process may cause the inmate pain and suffering, the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals said.
“For centuries, Mississippi sentenced to death only those who engaged in the most heinous forms of murder. Soon this practice will end as the state finally aligned its capital punishment regime with evolving standards in death penalty jurisprudence,” Judge James L. Dennis wrote on behalf of the three-judge panel.
The panel said the Supreme Court has “frequently reserved to the states the discretion to craft execution methods free of frivolous interference by federal courts.”
This principle assumes that “the state will abide by constitutional requirements and international norms, such as evidence to support the evidence of pain when administering the death penalty.”

The Predators will open the Stanley Cup playoffs at home next week with two games against an undetermined opponent.
The tremendous success of the Predators’ unexpected Stanley Cup Final run last season can be tied to its dedicated fans in millions, but the team will retain a fan-friendly ticket pricing policy for its playoff games, including its home games to open, May 15 and May 18.
All three tiers of tickets have been released starting at $150. It’s welcome news for casual customers who may have been discouraged from attending a Stanley Cup Final game last season. Those tickets averaged more than $300, the NHL said.
The relaxed policies come as most other arenas limit the sales of lower-tier tickets to reduce supply in a move to strong-arm suckers.
For added incentive, the Predators will sell the tickets at a 50/50 split to increase the lagging ticket resell value, and local sports websites like CollegeGamedayTix.com will offer the ticket sales without any middleman fees.

Addressing a business envelope correctly helps ensure that your letter gets to its intended recipient quickly. It’s important to follow standard practices for addressing correspondence, particularly if you are sending a letter to a large company with many departments. Failure to present the right information can mean the letter never reaches its destination. Luckily, knowing the proper business envelope address structure is relatively straightforward. Once you have the structure down pat and properly practice it, you’re sure to get your letters to their destination timely.
The business address includes the street address and any additional information that helps you get the letter to its destination within the building. In many cases, the building’s name or address may also be included in the address line. That gives the reader an immediate indicator of the place. In larger companies with multiple corporate units or departments, the business address could also contain the name of the recipient’s company department or unit. Other pieces of property information, such as suite or floor number, may also be included if necessary to get the letter to the proper department. Separating business address information can also help bracket the building name and department name from the street address information for better organizational

There's a lot of talk these days, and a lot of evidence, of school districts getting raked by layoffs, and by forced attrition—basically not filling positions when teachers and others leave, or retire.
In the next few weeks, most school districts will have to do some belt-tightening. Uniformed employees are protected by collective bargaining laws, and some faculty get that protection, too. The people left without any protections—teachers who are evergreen—feel the pinch of furlough days. Contractors feel the pinch even more, because the contractors who supply schools with maintenance and food services are probably not unionized.

Newswise — As more carbon dioxide enters the atmosphere, the global ocean soaks up much of the excess, giving scientists more tools to forecast how much of the greenhouse gas will boost sea-level rise.
Climate change science has increasingly focused on the ocean as most scientists consider it less hospitable than the atmosphere. A mixture of weaknesses and strengths in predicting the variation of atmospheric CO2 over many years makes it more difficult to use directly as a forecasting tool. The ocean borrows CO2 from the atmosphere, and the integrated amount in the surface of the ocean since 1830 gives a partial measure of the change. Moreover, since the oceans always absorb excess CO2, results from this topic have implications for the fundamental science underlying most forecasts of the rate of sea-level rise.

Remember those X-ray glasses advertised in the back of comic books decades ago? Sure, they promised to "See through walls!" or "Reveal hidden treasure!" But did anything ever come from them?
Engineers at the University of California, San Diego, are at least partly responsible for resurrecting the X-ray glasses—with a little help from a high-tech camera and computer video-analysis software.
Academic Radiographics, the journal of the American Association of Physicists in Medicine, featured the UC San Diego researchers and their work in its latest issue (Sep. 15). The professors are using software and electronics to construct a handheld device that reveals the unseen inner structure of adult and embryonic cells, as well as building components such as concrete and fiberglass.

Cara Simmons, right, and her sister, Glori Nicholson, react to news that she now owns a Cleveland Heights home.
CLEVELAND, Ohio -- Cara Simmons has never liked the color orange. So it was with some trepidation that she ushered a trio of Cleveland Heights officials inside the tax foreclosed home she owns on Park Road to see every inch of the place anew, guidebook in-hand.

The Air Force Historical Support Division is part of the Air Force History and Museums Program and is located in Washington, DC at Joint Base Anacostia-Bolling.
AFHSD is primarily the historical research and book writing arm of Air Force History and Museums. Books written by AFHSD historians have won the Army Historical Foundation's Feltman Award for writing the book best capturing "a key period and/or conflict or lessons of the past," as well as the American Society for Military History's Emory & Don Harward Award for "presentations on topics that illuminate the many different ways that history and the trade of history can vary and overlap among academic disciplines."

They will also be installing a barrier-type median, PennDOT said.
PennDOT said the companies performing the work are JSV in Hampton and Calvin Brothers in Bethlehem. The project will take several months to complete.
"I hope they get some strong winds so they initiate the flaps," Lacey McGuire said.

A man from Alsip has been charged with the fatal shooting of a 33-year-old man in the South Chicago neighborhood, police said.
Brandon Ewing, 24, of the 3700 block of South Alsdorf Avenue, was charged with first-degree murder in the Wednesday shooting of 33-year-old Herman Adamson, according to a statement from Chicago police released Friday.
Ewing was acting on behalf of an unidentified man when he fatally shot Adamson with a shotgun, the release said.
The statement said further details were not being released due to ongoing investigations.
Around 4 a.m. Wednesday, officers responded to a call of shots fired in the 9200 block of South Western, on the city’s Far South Side. Officers found Adamson suffering from multiple gunshot wounds to the body. He was pronounced dead on the scene a short time later, police said.
Later that morning, a 20-year-old man was shot and killed in Bronzeville, just hours after Adamson’s murder.

Dietrich Bonhoeffer has always been one of my great heroes of the faith. Such appreciation, of course, hardly makes me distinct. Bonhoeffer, the German pastor-theologian who opposed the Nazis and eventually faced the executioner, is one of the most widely loved and widely misunderstood theologians of the twentieth century.
The scenes for his fall came quickly. In one of the amazing ironies of World War II, Bonhoeffer returned to Germany from America to lead a major campaign against the theology and philosophy of the Nazis. A brilliant orator, he did his best in letters and visits to the leaders and scholars of Germany to bring Nazi atheism to its knees before the cross of Jesus Christ. In his famous letter of June 22, 1933, to his friend Franz Hildebrandt, Bonhoeffer wrote:
“Our business, as I see it, is simply this: to see to it that it goes on living somewhere, as will irrigate, nourish and make fruitful new springs, not as dry husks which are carried to miser

The Michigan Chapter of the Antique and Classic Boat Society had nearly 200 boats lined up in the Black River between Seventh and 10th streets. The previous record for an ACBS International Boat Show was 178 boats.
Black River Festival Headliner Neil Diamond joined final celebrity judges Gil Robertson IV and Anne Saxton for last year's "Georgia on My Mind" - decorated boat contest.
The Black River Festival will be holding its 41st annual Black River Festival on August 16 - August 25, 2013 at various locations throughout the city of Natchez, Wilmington and Vicksburg Mississippi and Vidalia Louisiana.
Each summer, the waterways of the civil war era mark the site of a distinctive showcase of rare boats mingled with antique and classic cars, side-by-side with period military artifacts, nautical art and much more.
For over forty summers, a Gathering of the Nations has been held in and around Natchez, Wilmington and Vicksburg on the banks of the lower Mississippi River.

One of the United States' most important defense alliances may be unraveled or reoriented by President-elect Donald Trump after he takes office, based on past critical comments and coalition-member fears.
For more than four decades, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) has served as the cornerstone of US global defense strategy.
Incorporated out of the decaying ashes of the World War II-era alliance known as the "Cold War," the pact isn't only between the US and European states. Nato — the world's most powerful weapon's cartel — includes countries 30 nations, including some of the most powerful countries on the planet.
In concept, the alliance should be a no-brainer; the United States controls the greatest military arsenal in human history, NATO is needed most when things go bad, and overall is an enabler for the international rules-based order that Europe and the US desperately needs to sustain.

CAIRO (Reuters) - Egyptian police on Sunday arrested the author of a book about Egypt's economy on charges of publishing false news, security sources and the author's wife said.
Abdul Khalik al-Shayeb, a former banker who now borders out of the Information Ministry, was taken to a police station from his home, his wife, Nour el-Etwo, told Reuters.
"There were about five or six cars carrying plainclothes police who came to arrest Shayeb over an incident regarding the poor readiness of the healthcare sector at a hospital in the south of the country," she said.
Egypt's economy has been in a tailspin as political turmoil and economic crises in recent years have sapped growth. The country faces a growing dependence on food and medicine imports that are prone to price hikes due to a sustained plunge in Egypt's pound.

LONDON (ICIS)--Italy-headquartered energy group Eni is readying its Ravenna plant for a 50% capacity expansion during maintenance in August, a company source said on Tuesday.
Italy is the world's fifth-largest derivatives exporter, behind South Korea, China, Taiwan and Japan. An expanded Ravenna should make flexibility easier in a busy trading hub in particular for Italy's spot market, the most liquid in Europe.
The upgrade has long been debated by market players, including some who have called for more expansions in Italy to ease spot derivative trading. A Reuters poll in 2010 pointed out that the refiner only operates 60-70% of its derivatives capacity despite the old plant being in its twelfth year of operation.
Eni came under pressure when maintaining the limits to derivative exports in a seaborne supply squeeze at the turn of the year in 2011. The move helped push spot import-made propane prices in northern Italy higher by $15/tonne over the period.

Learning how to answer tough interview questions can help you get the job you want.
Interview questions that ask you what you will contribute to the company are designed to help employers weed out the best applicants. Your answer to this question should clearly provide examples of your skills and experience and explain how they will help you perform the job and get promoted at your new job.
It's common to offer motivation or passion alongside your work history to help employers understand what makes you a good fit for the job.
The answer you provide may be slightly different if you name the skills that the position requires on its job posting or list them in your resume.
In the following sample answer, the applicant includes information about how they fit the job requirements as well as why the job appeals to them. She also shares how they will use their skills to succeed at work.

Aduro Biotech is laying off more than a third of its workforce in a restructuring intended to keep its focus on its cancer drugs now in clinical development.
The corporate shakeup will cut the Berkeley, California-based specialty pharma company's head count from 49 to 31 -- shipping out 16 people, keeping eight and going on a hiring freeze, company officials told BioWorld USA.
It involves Aduro scientists working on major sponsored research programs at the University of California, Berkeley. Earlier work focused on Natural Killer cell immunotherapy, now renamed Cytotoxic T-cell immunotherapy. Its flagship CpG-adjuvanted Listeria monocytogenes cancer vaccine platform was renamed with the current moniker of mTotec immunotherapy.

Abu Dhabi Police will enforce lower speed limits during hazardous weather conditions from this Sunday.
The force said reduced speed limits will be posted on electronic signboards on roads and sent out by SMS, the Arabic-language Khaleej Times said on Wednesday.
Police said drivers should be conscious of the traffic situation, road conditions and visibility conditions, according to Khaleej Times.
“Drivers should consider their vehicle’s different capacities and must drive safely, being mindful of the amount of people travelling in the vehicle,” Brigadier Saleh Abdel Azim Al Darmaki, Director of Automobile and Technical Affairs at Abu Dhabi Police, was quoted as saying.
He said drivers should also slow down as concentration levels would lower due to authorised accidents, Khaleej Times said.
Drivers were also warned that the fines for breaking speed limits would double in some areas of the UAE.
Individuals caught violating the speed limits face Dh1,000 to Dh3,000 fines.

That meeting, the first of three planned for the same purpose, will be held at one of the most important Catholic churches in the city, the St. Brendan Church, in the vicinity of the city’s Little Havana neighborhood.

Tom Brokaw says he did not intend for this “rough draft” of a letter to be widely read.
Brokaw, the former anchor of “NBC Nightly News,” is one of the country’s best-known broadcast journalists. In an essay published in Scientific American over the weekend, Brokaw grappled with the concept of citizenship and gratitude in America. He likened the enthusiastic singing of the national anthem in the post-9/11 years to joining “the old west cavalry – the Last Stand,” and chewed out “milquetoast marching bands.”
Nationalism, he wrote, is not for everyone. And “cultural picketing” is a “joyless thing, because to achieve… you have to denigrate others.” National anthems, he wrote, are a “powerful expression of the identity of a nation.”
In his letter, published in Scientific American last weekend, Brookaw compared the performance of the national anthem to a “cultural picketing with boos instead of cheers.” [Image: Nico Molina]

A picture of Rama (the words are a shortened form of Rayongkamagani, the Sanskrit name of the ruler, specifically denoting that he served the great born of Lord Vishnu) XI sits inside the silver chedi (a container for either ashes or relics, such as a tooth or sandal) where King Rama IX first.
Both chedis and Thai history are misteries to me (neither has been my deepest interest or focus in my years in country). A car called the Excel is to go on sale in the United States for the first time Thursday morning. It is an unremarkable looking vehicle, resembling many of the small, efficient Japanese cars that have wrested a large share of the American market from their U.S.-based predecessors.
But the Excel, a four-door hatchback ($16,004, including tax) being imported from Japan by Honda, was designed primarily as a motor that can switch from battery to gasoline, depending on the user's preference and the state of charge of the lithium-ion pack.
Honda's two-seat, five-speed Atkinson-cycle petrol engine and electric motor are under almost all the seats, including the front passenger. This makes the car lightweight, and the responsive drive gives the Excel class-leading acceleration figures.

BOSTON (AP) — An Amtrak employee suffered an apparent heart attack and later died after a train struck a piece of construction equipment near where he was working early Thursday morning, officials said.
The Albany, N.Y.-bound Capital Region Service train was en route from Portland, Maine to New York and hit the construction equipment at just after 6 a.m. in Springfield, Massachusetts State Police spokesman David Procopio said.
It was reported that the 49-year-old worker, named by Procopio as Ronald McGee, had become ill after the collision and was declared dead at a local hospital.
The extent of the damage to the Amtrak train wasn't immediately known, Procopio said.
Both Amtrak and Massachusetts-based Berkshire Rivers Railway announced they would suspend service for the rest of the day.
Amtrak also suspended service between New York and Boston between 8 a.m. and 11 a.m. due to a crew shortage caused by the collision. It said in a release that the delay would be for up to a half-hour.

Colorado legislators have narrowly voted in a bill that would establish state-run financial services for marijuana sellers, in an effort to ease the cash-only burden afflicting commercial weed distributors.
The bill passed by a 30 to 29 late vote Friday, legislators said. It now moves to Governor John Hickenlooper’s desk for his decision. Democrats hold a majority in both houses.
Among the main provisions: Requiring banks and credit unions to provide financial services to licensed marijuana ventures if those institutions deem them creditworthy. Transactions would have to comply with federal, state and local anti-money laundering regulations.
Lawmaker Tom Sullivan says the provisions would greatly benefit marijuana firms’ top business concern: Unreliable access to cash — via armored cars or other logistics — that could lead them to be safer investments for banks. Bangalore: In the U.S., top outsourcing customers such as Bank of America and several local governments are asking vendors such as TCS, Infosys and Wipro to deliver more projects locally. These requests for “nearshoring” are driven by rising development costs in traditional outsourcing destinations and increased risk in the U.S. of regulatory compliance violations and data breaches. Similarly in India, CRISIL, a Bangalore-based credit rating agency and risk analysis provider, has set up local centers in the U.S. and Europe. The stock of State-owned manganese-ore mining company MOIL is down by about 12 per cent in the last month. This seems to be largely on account of lower-than-estimated sales volumes and realising the somewhat lower prices the firm has been charging for its output. Investors seem to have got wind of the unrelenting rise in iron ore prices which began in August last year. Had iron ore not surged, MOIL may have been able to command higher prices for its output, it may not have faced problems in shipping its ore and selling it up north. In short, falling iron ore prices may have undercut MOIL’s prospects as a supplier to downstream user companies. That, however, has not emerged as a major worry for investors as MOIL is benefiting from several tailwinds other than iron ore-macro demand linkages.

The final group of Irish peacekeepers to serve in Chad arrived back in Dublin this afternoon.
For the first time in three decades, there are now no large Irish battalions serving overseas.
The 180 members of the touring ‘Dublin’ Battalion’ were departing the Bunia base camp in Chad after 21 months in that country, Burundi and the Central African Republic.
One soldier was killed in action when a colleague’s sentry rifle accidentally discharged while they were on heightened security.
That event prompted a re-deployment from rural areas to a more secure north-eastern town in Chad.
This afternoon, an Air Corps AW139 aircraft carrying the military contingent left Chad with a last stop at Altena airbase in neighbouring Germany.

Encouraging good eating habits in children, sustainable diets and food as medicine will be among the topics discussed at a major event this weekend.
Food for Thought at the School of Artisan Food over the weekend will see 80 exhibitors host cooking demonstrations, classroom-style discussions and stalls.
Discussions and talks will focus on topics such as healthy eating, slow food and the local food experience, as well as agriculture and food technology.
Organised by The British Library and the School of Artisan Food, the event will also take a look at how we can protect and support local producers and how we can make positive steps to sustainability.
It will take place at the Library site in Boston Spa, near Wetherby, over July 6-8.

The US economy “remains strong”, the Federal Reserve chairman, Jerome Powell, told Congress on Tuesday as he signaled the central bank is on course to carry on gradually increasing interest rates in the coming months.
In his prepared opening statement, Powell said GDP growth has rebounded in the second and third quarters after being flat in the first, which followed a long period of below-target inflation. It was good news, the Fed chief said, for “near- and long-term prospects for continued strengthening of the US economy”.
“I expect that, for now, we will see continued solid growth, accompanied by further gradual increases in the federal funds rate to keep the economy growing near its potential,” he is quoted as saying.

A message in a bottle that washed up more than 108 years after it was thrown into the sea may be the world's oldest, a marine association has said.
The bottle was released in the North Sea between the Netherlands and Sweden by Henry Spille in 1886.
It was found by the crew of a cargo ship in 2003 and returned to the Dutch trader, who gave it to Scandinavian coast guards to confirm the letter's age.
Mr Spille asked if the bottle washed ashore in future to answer back and sent the present bottle along with the letter.
It was found among the debris of a ship cargo that wrecked on the Pole heading from Indonesia to Europe in 2012.
Koen van Someren, chairman of the Dutch Pelagic Association, said: "The association doesn't claim records, but after careful consideration it seems that what is found is perhaps the oldest message in a bottle.

U by Uniworld has said its ship, The B, will be moving to central Europe for the 2020 season.
With increasing demand for the region, where sister ship The A also resides, The B will cease sailings in Morocco and replace The Taku with Creativity & Cocktails itineraries between Prague and Budapest.
For the 46 cabins onboard the ship, they will continue to sail with the same voyages, itineraries, inclusions and crew and, as a result, the designated ship of the sailings will receive the Letter Scenario name, which launched with The A.
This new name is derived from the letters in the name of the destinations that they stop in on their respective sailings.
The journeys operate as three to seven night itineraries, stopping at Prague, Vienna, Bratislava, Budapest – and now Belgrade – on fixed dates all year round.
The region is considered by the line to be high in art, culture and history, and also features cities that have embraced the cuisine and cocktails ethos of the brand.

Did van Gogh cut off his ear because his brother was engaged?
AMSTERDAM - New evidence has bolstered a theory that Vincent van Gogh's psychotic break on Dec 23, 1888, was preceded by excessive drinking.
Somewhere in the past four decades the theory that he cut of his ear by choice, has begun to break from the mainstream. But the most devastating consensus has been about why he did it.
In one version, van Gogh did it as a talisman, to bring good luck to his longtime lover, the prostitute Rachel - it’s widely and wrongly accepted at this point- who was in another lover's arms. In another story, the ear fell on a chamber pot. In a third, the wounded van Gogh drank absinthe, then chased it with a raging fever. A fourth claims he suffered from head trauma and likely brain damage. The current working theory is that van Gogh cut off his ear because he suffered from advanced alcoholism and paranoia.

Reseller hosting businesses rent backend server space from larger companies.
2 Can You Make Money Being a Web-hosting Reseller?
Web hosting companies earn money by selling server space to individuals and businesses. While some larger companies may host thousands of websites, smaller companies can only accommodate a handful of websites at a time. To meet higher demand from clients, smaller companies may rent server resources from larger vendors. As a result, reseller hosting companies rent server space from larger providers and resell that space to smaller companies. Instead of renting physical space on the provider's server, you will be essentially reselling the provider's services. This allows more people to enjoy cheaper hosting solutions.
Reseller hosting begins with a hosting company, which rents server space to individual web hosts. They are known as web hosts because they sell server space to individuals and businesses to create and operate websites. The reason these smaller web hosts require server space comes down to economies of scale; the provider has the fixed costs necessary to maintain a data center. This includes server equipment, power and more. Small businesses simply don't have that capacity to provide all of their clients (and

The rate of babies who die during their first year of birth has improved nationally in the last decade, but in recent years, improvement in this key public health metric has plateaued.

(CNN) — Elephants are giant, cancer-battling super creatures that destroy damaged cells long before they become cancerous, scientists say.
In a study released this week, scientists said elephant cells known as “spindle cells” work on damaged DNA before it becomes dangerous. The discovery may help scientists fight back against cancer as well as other public health concerns, such as the Zika virus.
“Spindle cells” act like excavators, the scientists said. They search for and destroy unwanted DNA sequences before they can become cancerous or prevent a Zika infection from spreading.
“The elephant cells are responding swiftly to what is a very rare event,” said Prof. Lee Berke of the public health school San Diego State University, one of the lead authors of the study published in the journal PNAS. The elephant discovered the connection between Zika infection levels and damaged DNA, opening up the possibility of early screening and prevention.

Yogis may be enjoying a surprising benefit when they unroll their mats and strike a pose. A new study finds that just 20 minutes of hatha yoga stimulates brain function.
Researchers from the Division of Life Sciences at the Arizona State University Bob and Dolores Hope Center for Brain Health examined eight people in their 70s. All of them were overweight and had both hemispheres in their brains that were fairly active. “The generic effect of doing any kind of bodily activity for this population was to quiet the brain,” says study co-author Gina Poe, who worked in conjunction with yoga instructor Angela Hicks to cobble together special 40-minute yoga classes expressly designed to meet the needs and limitations of the older adults.
For each of the eight exercise sessions, the scientists placed electrodes on the participants’ scalps and measured electrical signals flowing through brain areas not associated with regular movement or conscious thinking. New analysis shows 22 of Australia’s largest companies are actively working to undermine the Paris agreement targets, betting shareholders’ money on strategies that assume global climate change action fails.
Investor action group Market Forces took a closer look at energy, mining, timber and logistics businesses that dominate the ASX300 – more than half (132) of which have significant fossil fuel reserves.
It found two-dozen companies are actively planning for, investing in, or supplying the fossil fuels needed to meet that demand, despite a 76 per cent cut, to 1.5 degrees, in global carbon pollution levels needed to avert the worst of the climate crisis, it said.

Composting is the ultimate win-win-win for gardeners.
It is recycling at its most basic, turning yard and kitchen waste into rich, organic planting material. It saves money on fertilizer and chemicals at a time when they cost more and have become a rarer commodity. It helps with water conservation, a time-honored value in arid climates. In urban and suburban settings, it often reorients backyards and gardens in a spirit-lifting way that renew our connection to the land.
If you have a vegetable or fruit garden, as I do, compost is your best friend. But as any cook knows, it can be tough to decide how to saute greens, for instance, and when potatoes are ready to be baked. Gardeners so often experience the same challenges figuring out what can go into the compost pile and what should not.

Odds are you've watched your favorite show on Netflix enough times to pick up on the overarching plot no matter what episode you're watching. Of course, you can manually choose an episode at "random," but the show will always resume where it left off.
For example, if you press play on personality show Jane the Virgin, the streaming service will take you to a different part of the action. But, if you want to pick any episode and get snippets from different parts of the series, then click that "random episode."
Your episode descriptions will still be intact, so you'll know what you're in for, such as "porque te enojas, Jane."
The "random episode" button is a nice little feature that's been included for years. It's effective and definitely gives you a different angle on how they present you with the next episode. It might not entirely alter the plot line, but imagine our surprise the clarity our minds would have if it did. Instead, what do we do when we hit the mysterious button? We simply watch each episode in its entirety.

Stanley Karnow, the award-winning author and journalist who wrote a definitive book about the Vietnam War, worked on an accompanying documentary and later won a Pulitzer for a history of the Philippines, died Sunday morning. He was 88.
Karnow died of pneumonia at a hospital in Washington, D.C. Karnow’s daughter Frances Dunnery said her father died early Sunday at Sibley Hospital, one day after suffering a stroke.
Karnow covered more than 25 years of the global news cycle beginning with Pakistan in 1959, He lived six decades in five and a half different countries. He was based out of the Washington Post’s news bureau in Tokyo in 1967-1975. His history of Vietnam was called Vietnam: A History and he wrote a 2001 biography of John Hope Franklin, one of the pioneering African-American experts on the history of slavery.
The Washington, D.C.-based Post announced Karnow’s death.
Vietnam: A History might be Karnow’s enduring contribution to journalism

The “car chase” is another carryover from The Bourne Identity that Director Greengrass includes yet improves upon. Supremacy takes the cliché car chase, injects it with steroids, and chases itself in the trackless mountains of the Czech Republic in Atlassia. It becomes a fiercely spirited contest of "I'm Alpha, the faster, more precise driver". The chase becomes not only an exceptionally compelling last 15-minutes of the film, but it is an exemplary climax to a well-made effort by Greengrass: fluid, kinetic, and suspenseful.
Supremacy: 4/5 stars.

A report by the Wall Street Journal suggests that Dell could be on the verge of becoming a public company once again.
The deal could be announced as soon as later today and -- if the cited sources close to Dell are correct -- the $25 billion sale would slash Dell's debt by half. It could also be activist investor Carl Icahn's chance to claim some of the company.
It all comes after two years of speculation about Dell's attempts to take the PC maker private. Now, analysts claim to believe the company's buyout of itself is imminent. Investors are poised to "profit from a couple of weeks of trading Dell's shares while it is owned privately," sources noted to Bloomberg last week, while the company "still would sell to a strategic caller."
The sale of its PC division has been part of Michael Dell's plan ever since he surprised investors by talking privately with shareholders about how one offer -- reported at up to $15 billion -- didn't give him the "control and flexibility" he wanted.

Decision trees help people identify the pros and cons of business choices.
A decision tree is a visual tool used to help business professionals weigh the pros, cons and various approaches to major tasks or decisions. A decision tree can help professionals identify which options, including the pros and cons of each choice, have the most potential to be successful. Sometimes decision trees bear the name of information-gathering diagrams. While decision trees, similar to flowcharts, help clarify a procedure, they can also help people identify potential mistakes.
Decision trees, similar to information-gathering diagrams, can be used for various uses.
Decision trees help define how a business decision will be made. They show each step or stage in a decision-making process, and the possible outcomes. For example, to identify a possible client and best service provider to meet financial goals, a financial advisor could create an organized framework to diagnose the steps she should take with her clients to match them to the right providers. Decision trees also can be used to identify the characteristics of a successful client rather than relying on the criteria of an unsuccessful client.
