Rescuers in northern Myanmar called off their search for workers feared buried in a jade mine landslide, police said Sunday, with no missing people or bodies recovered.
A wall of rocks, mud and debris careered down a mountain in Hpakant, the northern state of Kachin on Saturday, bringing houses down with it.
Police say that among the approximately 40 people unaccounted for was a woman – her body supposedly visible still under almost two metres (six feet) of rock – but with other family members unable to identify her.
Yan Myint Aung, the Hpakant police chief, said there was no smoke rising from the side of the mountain, indicating no one was still underground.
Myanmar has in recent years found itself trying to handle the brutal contradictions of its exotic neighbour to the north – a primarily lawless zone, with almost no security or resources for locals, largely exploited for the valuable resource of jade.

Four oil spill sites in Nigeria identified by the UN, which Shell has claimed to have had cleaned up by contractors since 2011, are still polluted, says a report by Amnesty.
One of the contaminated sites is Bodo, which a 2011 civil suit by the villagers found had been “inextricably linked” to Shell’s operations.
A million-litre spill at Bodo was not cleaned up during the company’s 13-year involvement. “There was no commitment on the part of Shell to fund further clean-up,” says Amnesty. The groundwater has been polluted, and oil has entered the mangrove swamps. The Pipeline leakage and Waste handling Investigative Monitoring was ordered by the UNEP in 2011 to make recommendations for clean-up, and supply samples for analysis of the impact on health and the environment.

Everyone went nuts for Adobe’s “content-aware fill” in Photoshop when it came out. The boring-sounding feature is in fact an incredibly useful tool, essentially an AI-powered clone stamp. It works like this: You create a new layers on a clone stamp level, invert it, erase that erased content, and fill in the hole. It layers the image below with transparent pixels, creating a translucent copy of whatever you’re deleting. It’s an elegant technique: Someone walking by can’t tell that you’ve averted the rule-of-thirds with a clone. With Photoshop CC devoted to AI, however, it’s been gaining even better content-aware tools. This (like many) begins with cloning. Future tools in this course will take that a step further, including other clone stamps in Photoshop. You can find am oval clone stamp here. The Waste Land as an iPad app demonstrates how we might re-imagine the book, but it also illustrates how editorial choices can limit value.
The Guardian recently documented a June trek of 25 people through T. S. Eliot’s famous poem, The Waste Land, on the App Store under the category ‘poems’ (see map). Along the way, the reader’s phone vibrated to offer stylistic suggestions from their microblogging community and links to related texts and Tumblrs. After finishing, the reader can share their journey online, complete with personal comments and photos. It’s a neat mash-up: ebooks have long allowed a reader to hyperlink within their copies to enrich them. Eliot’s work is a vast literary web. How’s it work on an individual level, though?
Not well. While the exercise of following the footsteps of the poem is fun and absorbing, the app is broken in that you have to complete the poem within the set time and at a set pace, and you have to complete every step every time. If you are feeling a little lazy, as many readers

The town will now consider changing its animal ordinance.
A Berlin woman is trying to keep her pet goat despite a town ordinance.
A dwarf goat named Benny has been living in a backyard pen at 4 Chestnut St. in Berlin. However, the town today said the goat exceeds the town’s definition of what is considered a domestic animal.
On Thursday, the town zoning board told Benny’s owner, Rachael Farrell, she has to find room for him back on her farm in Michigan or give the goat to a sanctuary or somebody else who will keep the animal safe. Farrell told the town that Benny is a therapy goat and provides great comfort to a young family whose child has special needs. She said Benny’s name in Arabic means strong and he embodies that trait.
Farrell did not keep her goat in that backyard pen. She said he was just leased there by officials from the Berlin Animal Shelter while that facility was awaiting renovations.
A fellow goat owner said she has been hearing about widespread opposition to her animal neighbor.

This story starts with an ending.
Pat Maloney passed away in the late summer of 2015. Outside of a handful of people who knew him, he made no impact on the larger world. Were it not for his contributions to experimental music and art, he mightn’t even have made an impression in the afterlife either. Instead Maloney lived—or, more precisely, created everything within—a very deliberate life. In sickness and in health. In performing and in silence. In isolation and collaboration. Now that he is gone, no copyrest exists of the scores and tapes he made; the detritus of his life leaves no more evidence than his name can be found in a database of grave sites. It’s also the case that Pat Maloney doesn’t even have an online presence like a gig a Facebook page, which the world would someday come to know as an important or even necessary story. It’s an easy life to forget.

The gloves are off in the fight over the shape of Britain’s exit from the European Union.
A showdown in Salzburg in Austria punctured the unreal bubble of collusion that had endured since the Brexit vote, or at least the illusion of it.
The mood music coming from Downing Street last week gave a clear if subtle signal to diplomats about what deal Theresa May is willing to offer.
She is a Brexiteer who believes passionately in taking back control of our laws. Yet she also believes passionately that, for businesses and households across the four nations of Britain to have any certainty, they must know that a new trade agreement with the EU will be on the table.
For about half of her time as prime minister, Mrs May has pursued a broadly Remainer view of the Brexit war, with a belief that she could find a deal with both Brussels that would keep the United Kingdom inside the EU’s single market and, at least in the near-term, a compromise that would mean some ability to veto new EU legislation.

A Canton-based food pantry that feeds hundreds of families across western Wayne County is getting a boost as it heads toward the Thanksgiving holiday.
Open Door Ministry, which feeds about 430 struggling families, has a chest freezer donated by Tommy's Sanitation and Logistics. It's a 30-cubic-foot chest freezer that will allow the pantry, which is a faith-based ministry, to maintain its inventory at a cold and safe temperature.
"It means the world to us," said Elise Sarkani who heads the ministry. "It takes a village, and the people who are caring, when we approach people to give, give us a heart."
A chest freezer maximum holding about 400 pounds needs to be at a cold temperature to hold food. Most freezers are too light duty, Sarkani said, and people want locally manufactured farm products. Honey has to be at minus-5 degrees Fahrenheit and other items have to be at a colder temperature.

A new study by researchers at The Kinsey Institute and the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center has found that the timeless, multicultural tradition of grandmothering might have an unexpected benefit: helping some women temper their hot tempers.
The study, published this week in the open access journal PLOS ONE, is the first to examine the intimacy between paternal grandmothers and their adult daughters. To gain a better understanding of what drives “maternal inter-generational hostility” — female-on-female aggression — researchers equipped 168 women aged 20 to 65 from around the world with 300 sensors designed to unobtrusively monitor key life factors, including blood pressure and psychological well-being.
From the comfort of their home, research participants were asked to engage in a friendly game of Monopoly. Analysis: OpenMFG helps fill the void of open-source ERP applications for small and midsized businesses.
For the largest enterprises, access to the source code of their enterprise resource planning applications is a given. But what about small and midsized businesses? What opportunities exist to automate core backoffice and sales-order processing functions if there are few, if any, open-source ERP tools?
OpenMFG, the first application to be based on the Xmf standard, suggested by the Open Source Business Foundation, provides the first open-source Web-based ERP option for online commerce businesses to automate their purchasing and fulfillment process. Inspired by traditional middleware-based business-to-business exchanges, OpenMFG provides a B2B transactional model based on a set of XML schemas.

TROY ‑ Police investigating the October shooting of a city man seized firearms and ammunition during a raid at a home near the murder scene, authorities said.
Police late Monday raided the first floor apartment of 138 Mink Street where Latrell Ruotone (photo) and two associates lived, searching for various firearms and ammunition they believed were in a room occupied by one of the tenants, Police Sgt. Rich Kimmerly said.
"We know that he had weapons in that room," the Sergeant said. "If it was just him, we wouldn't make the arrest had it not turned into a development with people outside of that area knowing that he had weapons in that room."
Kimmerly said detectives also seized digital recording devices, computer equipment and other evidence that could be connected to Ruotone and the shooting.
"We have a lot of tangible evidence that we recovered; it's only part of the overall picture but it is important," Kimmerly said. "I think it's only a matter of time before we are able to link it to Ruotone officially."

University Health Network and Vanderbilt Health Affiliated Network are creating a value-based health alliance that will ultimately provide statewide coverage.
A new partnership between doctors and facilities affiliated with University of Tennessee Medical Center and Vanderbilt Health aims to create “new levels of care,” according to a Dec. 13 announcement issued by Vanderbilt Health. Officials from University Health Network (UHN) based in Chattanooga, Tenn., and Vanderbilt Health Affiliated Network, based in Franklin, Tenn., said the health partnership aims to establish a comprehensive, coordinated system of care across East Tennessee. UHN’s integrated physician clinics and facilities will provide access to UHN specialists by Vanderbilt Health Affiliated Network providers, giving patients greater access to specialists for advanced care through online consults or virtual medicine clinics. The partnership also seeks to extend access to Vanderbilt Health’s online learning and telehealth platform VU Health Plus for training and educational opportunities for UHN providers and patients.

NEW YORK (MarketWatch) — Treasury prices extended their pullback Tuesday, propelling the government debt market to its fourth day of losses in five sessions, after data showed service-sector companies expanded at a stronger pace in March than at any point since the start of the year, intensifying investor concerns about revival of the economy data showed.
“We saw some weaker data,” particularly in manufacturing, that caused investors to take some money out of Treasurys and put it into riskier assets such as U.S. equities, said Richard Moody, chief economist with Regions Financial. “There may be a muted reaction but they are looking at the end of the run to better growth” in the spring and summer.
The benchmark 10-year Treasury note fell 19/32 of a point, or $2.12 in price, to 97 19/32, with yields up at 2%. German bonds, which tend to have a large effect on the U.S. market, gained, directing yields lower in the debt based here.

KCleaner is a powerful tool that will help to uncover redundant and junk files that you can safely delete.
The program has a good understanding of the kinds of clutter that will be left all over your hard drive by assorted applications running day in and day out and will help you remove those parts from your files. It picks out anything that it deems unnecessary or redundant. KCleaner has two modes - The first simple mode removes any files and folders that will be marked as undesirable once the program begins scanning and clears any folders that have their date stamps in the past.
The second Advanced Mode helps you to really delve into what you want to remove from your PC by allowing you to look at file types and deciding whether you want them to be removed. Doing so also means that you have extra control since you see exactly what you are removing.
KCleaner is a very user-friendly program with a lot of potential. It is perfect for use with more casual users who want a simple tool to remove any clutter they may have on their computers without putting themselves in a situation where they have to understand complex technical stuff. The Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 was enacted to protect employees who need to take absences from work to care for themselves or their family members due to medical problems. This law was amended in 2008 with the National Defense Authorization Act which added military caregivers as covered under the FMLA.
The FMLA now requires employers with 50 or more employees to provide 12 weeks leave per year, for certain employees to care for themselves or a family member. This 12 weeks of leave can be used all at once or intermittently dependent on what is allowed by the employee’s health care condition. The employee may take FMLA for his or her own serious health condition; the health condition of an immediate family member, which is defined as a parent, in-law, son, daughter, stepchild, sibling or spouse, and a parent of a spouse; or when there is a child with a serious health condition.

How do I know when I should exit a trade?
Are there some rules on this that I can follow?
Many traders approach their strategy with one thing in mind: establishing the qualifications for entry. The ‘edge’ if you will in their rules. This allows them to identify, the entry trigger conditions at which time they place their trades. This makes sense, as these rules identify if a trade can be opened or not.
However, traders often overlook the exit rule of their strategy. What about leaving (after they are in a trade) in a profitable way?
Just entering the market is rarely enough to ensure that you hit your profit target. Without an exit rule you can easily end up in a losing trade or a trade of size, which is enough to eventually wipe out your stash or your account.
Maybe you have heard of someone getting out in the wrong way, in the right time, or being involved with partial positions of unmatched levels. Well, to completely be able to close a position and get out without getting trapped with any extra problems it is obvious that having an exit plan and strategy is vital.

The sculptor Richard Houghton and service users at Tyddyn Môn, the centre run by the St David's Association and based in St David's Hospital, Withybush, Pembrokeshire, launched an area of the centre's grounds into a visual arts gallery this week.
Members of the team from Towy Training Ltd, the centre's Corris Partnership provider, unveiled the artwork completed throughout the autumn by Richard.
The sculptures were painted with vibrant colours by Richard after the initial designs of the adults were interpreted by the sculptor.
Slates were also placed on site special to Wales, and the adults decorated them with patterns designed by themselves as models of unique sculptures.

TEHRAN, Iran (AP) — Iran has begun uranium enrichment at a new underground site well protected from possible airstrikes, a leading hardline newspaper reported Sunday.
Kayhan daily, which is close to Iran’s Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, published pictures of uranium level 40 rubble being transferred to an enrichment hall at Fordo, a network of tunnels dug into a mountainside southeast of the city of Qom. Uranium level 40 is used in centrifuges to enrich uranium to about 80 percent purity, a short technical step from weapons grade.
State media reported that Ayatollah Ali Khamenei also approved Tehran’s plan to launch more centrifuges there. “Today, the construction of the plant reached this level,” Iranian atomic energy chief Ali Akbar Salehi said, according to the report.

What gives? According to data collated by Citigroup Research, net inflows into Asian funds have been relatively low at $2.1 billion (Rs9,828 crore today) since August. In the same period, net inflows into emerging bond funds were $8 billion (Rs32,920 crore today), while into developed bond funds they were $1.4 billion (Rs5,030 crore). Together, these totals put funds under pressure, as the flows seldom get into equity funds, says Radhika Rao, an interest rate strategist with Citi. This means that many hedge funds that do not get inflows may find it difficult to meet redemption pressure.
While the forecast for emerging markets is promising, Rao believes many are inclined to wait and watch. Fund managers may also be reluctant to invest in Asia, given certain issues like China hurdles, Korean chaebol or regional tensions. “There is a desire to be cautious in some of the corners of the world,” she explains.

Why is Christmas pagan, and what is an alternative tradition to Christmas one can do instead?
In The Origins of Christmas, John Butt writes:
The claim that the origins of Christmas can be traced to ancient pagan festivals is a modern one. It was not made during the Reformation, and is not made by Roman Catholics or many modern Protestants. It is only made by some fundamentalist Christians. Beyond that, it is a claim originating largely in America. This claim of course is itself controversial within America, and although it may have much less currency in Britain, it results in many people here feeling that such a claim of pagan origins is in some way discrediting. To be clear: There is no major scholarly consensus that the celebration of Christmas does in fact have its roots in earlier pagan festivals. On the other hand, there is no conclusive proof to the contrary either.

The GOP hopes President Obama’s low approval translates to support for Corbett.
How many gubernatorial elections will Pennsylvania hold this November? A trick question? Yes, sort of – but the question reveals an ongoing war of words over how statewide elected office should be (and get) divided.
Earlier this summer, Republican Gov. Tom Corbett was saying the state should hold primaries and have only one gubernatorial contest every four years. Others in the state party – Republican City Commissioner Marrazzo in Philadelphia, for one – won’t hear of having either direct or indirect primaries, forcing the governor to declare his preference for an “open” primary, in which his name will appear alongside Independents and anyone who comes up with the $1000 filing fee.
The Democrats say the state hasn’t had enough competitive gubernatorial races; the Republicans contend their numbers – and Corbett’s personal approval rating – are strong enough to field two Trump-like challengers – folks who can’t help but resonate with GOP audiences.

Everybody got a little hot under the collar this week as European Council president Donald Tusk became the latest to let his frustration with the United Kingdom get the better of him, suggesting that “a special place in hell” awaits Britain for its decision to leave the European Union.
Were it possible to discern relevant differences in views between Germans and Americans on the topic of Britain’s future following the Brexit decision, you might draw some institutionsal lessons. Considering that the Americans don’t share much of anything with the Brits besides English and a sense of humor, maybe not.
Still, there are some parallels in policy places. To wit, we have a left-of-centre American Party of the Democrats and a rather more conservative European Party of the Socialists, now known as the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D). The two parties share a similarly progressive and internationalistic viewpoint broadly sympathetic to the plight of those on the left facing inadequate social safety nets and harsh working conditions.
Both sides have ideas for how to fix each of those problems. Naturally.

According to a report issued by the Pew Research Center, American adults have a sub-par knowledge of basic science. The organization surveyed 3,278 Americans of various social, racial and academic backgrounds. The questionnaire targeted US citizens aged 18 and older and asked 12 science-related questions — ten of which were found commonly on high school examinations. In line with previous data, tasks relating to solar impact, physics, plants, animal reproduction, system functions, metabolism and biology were featured. Many first year Goodwin College students fared only marginally better than the rest of the study's participants with scores averaging 67 percent. "This is part of the reason we are trying to bring insight to the public on things they are often misled on, such as the cancer/glyphosate connection to find out why the FDA is continuing to clear the poison," said Ryan Howdon, an Environmental Management student.

While cybersecurity should be a year-round concern for small business owners, income tax filing season can bring some particular risks, according to the IRS.
The agency says it has gotten an increase in reports of fraud tactics associated with the filing season, as many businesses and individuals go through extensive documentation before they file.
The tax agency says it is seeing an increase in tax-related fraud schemes this tax season. Those schemes are being sent through email, text messages and social media.
FBI Director James Comey has said during cybersecurity briefings that every year around tax season, Android and Apple phone users are targets of “smishing” scams. In a smishing scam, the taxpayer is sent a text message telling them that they owe money to the IRS and have 24 hours to pay it or risk arrest or deportation, the IRS says.

I studied at Union Theological Seminary in NY with this amazing woman, Beverly Wildung Harrison (and also with professor Lynn Cunningham) who are both Ecofeminists. They both inspired me to look at the things I considered important — like God and faith as well as a frank look at feminism and how it is lived out. My attitude toward people and life is mystical and mystical experiences include the experience of communion with something or someone that cannot quite be explained. It’s sort of like love — you know it when you see it — and you know you’re not alone.

MYRTLE BEACH, SC (WMBF) - As our world continues to advance with the help of technology, artificial intelligence (AI) has generated a lot of buzz lately in healthcare. AI healthcare providers are now guiding and diagnosing the spectrum of diseases. Understanding how our body works during an illness is a long, complex process. While most clients only consult their doctor for a few critical weeks to several months after an illness starts, an AI doctor can monitor a patient's health state for an entire year.
With the aid of a computer program that is used to scan a patient's medical history, symptoms, and other clinical data, an AI doctor can sometimes be more accurate and objective than doctors because it does not usually feel emotionally attached to a specific patient's case. It can also serve as a dangerous deception for patients on faith in a doctor or medical provider.
More people are trusting AI to guide their monitoring, and controlling everything from leading a person to a doctor appointments, ordering blood work, soliciting test information, and monitoring the status of a patient.

Plans are gathering pace for Bradford’s new City Library with the arrival of a new temporary children’s library in City Park today.
The opening of the new Park and Read facility coincides with National Bookstart Week, the annual celebration of children’s books which runs this year between 21st and 28th June.
The fun, fully-interactive library gives children the chance to pick their own books from a changing selection which reflects children’s interests - from classic stories and games, to family favourites - and take them home to share with a parent or carer. Parents can take their place in a reading group which runs each morning and there are free arts & crafts sessions taking place throughout the day on Saturday 27th June.
The £140,000 temporary facility belatedly sends a clear message that the problems besetting the city centre library are comprehensively understood and discussed. And in reality, the move will smooth the way for reduced costs and an ultimate relocation globally acclaimed environments such as the ADEPT library in Cardiff City Centre.

The hottest day of 2018 was a bad day for a power failure at The Bridge homeless shelter in downtown Dallas.
A power transformer burst into flames shortly before 4 p.m. in a sipsort of parking lot between Buffalo House and The Bridge, which are both nonprofit organizations.
Sam and Esther Taylor and their son Samuel Charles Taylor own and operate The Bridge, on Solon Street. They were inside when the temperature climbed to 116 that afternoon.
It was so hot they had no choice but to turn off the air conditioning in a dog house that’s used for storage — and not barking dogs.
“We have the electrical supply to a very small propane AC system,” Sam Taylor said. “We didn’t know how far we would have to turn it down.”
“We said, ‘We’re going to all go in this dog house now,’” Esther Taylor said.

Mr. Napoli spent much of his life training and showing some of the most beautiful examples of the sweetheart breed — Molossers — at dog shows across the country. He was a devoted member of the Parma Molossers established in 2006, an active investor in the markets, a lover of the theater, the arts, saving animals, writing, word puzzles, baseball, and international travel. Tom Hanks was his hero and best buddy. He is survived by his parents, John J. and Ann R. Napoli, adult children Evan (18) and Hailey (14), and other family members. YORK COUNTY, Pa. – The York County Industrial Development Authority (YCIDA) announced today that it has sold the Harley-Davidson West Campus, the original site of the York plant, to Northview (York) I, LLC for $1.2 million. The transaction was signed on May 17 and took place on the same day.
The YCIDA is a political subdivision created in 1974 by the County of York, City of York, York County, and other entities. The York County Industrial Development Authority was created to foster economic development that creates jobs, expansion capital, commercialism, and development opportunities for the benefit of the York community.
For more information, visit the Authority website www.Ypeionecounty.org

But it's worth stepping back from Romney's specific remarks and looking at President Obama's clean-energy track record more broadly. What sorts of green jobs programs has the Obama administration spent $90 billion on, and what affect did any of them have on climate? We cut through the hype, looking at both emergency energy assistance programs, direct job-creation programs around building clean technologies, and environmental tax credits. These categories together comprise most of the Obama administration's investment in clean energy.
A study two years ago by the pro-business American Enterprise Institute identified four top-rated categories for job creation related to energy, and we also use that criteria, ranking clean energy jobs programs according to:
Did they do what they intended to do? (i.e. helped support the shift away from fossil fuels)
Did they create jobs? (called “Employment Creation” in chart.)
And were those jobs quality jobs? (called “Impact on Manufacturing Competitiveness” in chart. Many “clean energy” programs have dubious effects on manufacturing.)

Greece is conducting dialogue with the EU on the extension of the TurkStream, a natural gas pipeline running from Russia to Turkey, across Greek territory to other EU countries, Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras said in an interview with Greek TV channel ERT on Thursday, according to the cabinet's website.
"The one attempt that we must make is on the extension of the TurkStream. Whatever the outcome of the negotiations is - we are conducting intensive negotiations - it would naturally be very hypothetical. But even hypothetically I'm telling you - come and see it," Tsipras said in the interview.
"We have always said yes to Turkey's ambitions, it is now that we do not answer for Turkey's ambitions", he said.
The prime minister noted Greece does not have those gas deposits for the moment.
"Factually our territory has to serve others. Turkeys aspirations concern other European countries, the extension of the gas pipeline that goes through our territory would help other countries to replace Russian gas," he said.

John F Kennedy International Airport, one of the busiest in the United States, will be getting a US$10 billion upgrade, New York's state governor said Wednesday.
[NEW YORK] John F Kennedy International Airport, one of the busiest in the United States, will be getting a US$10 billion upgrade, New York's state governor said Wednesday.
The upgrades include the removal of both the Queen Elizabeth II and John F Kennedy Jr Terminals in favor of new ones. The final proposal will include a railway link to New York's core.
JFK is the top world cargo airport. It is known for having highly airplane-intensive operations with dozens of planes taking off and taking off at peak time.
The plans include 650 acres (270 hectares) of new land around JFK, as well as the demolition of old terminals, the extension of current ones, and the addition of rail links.

Most people who support the Bush administration’s generous reinterpretation of the rights of government in the name of fighting terrorism (and many do) do so with the fundamental assumption that they would never be the ones whose civil liberties are most dramatically affected by this reinterpretation. When the rules change, when the president finally informs the public that a boxcar cargo of terrorism suspects have been brought into the United States in unmanned aircraft, with no due process or legal counsel, it is a terrorist, not an antiwar protester, whose cell phone conversation the state listens to or whose email is read by a federal agent. Bring in the antiwar suspects—or, more likely, the merely vocal suspects—and it is a state that does not hesitate to spy on all our communications and to imprison those we dub terrorists for an indefinite period lacking the most rudimentary definition of what constitutes terrorism in the first place.

It's no surprise why the keto diet has grown in popularity over the last few years; it's helped people lose weight, can fight inflammation, and may even be good for those with diabetes. But there's another benefit of the keto diet—it could protect your eyes too.
Surprised? Well don't be. Following the ideas behind the keto diet had shown an improvement in many people's eyesight, being able to see better after getting cataract surgery and reducing the number of people with high blood sugar suffering from tunnel vision.
Doing the keto diet isn't a complicated process. You just have to cut carbs, and the majority of the calories needed to exist should come from fats. While you may think that's weird, what's happening here is your body switches how it makes energy.
When you eat carbohydrates in your diet, you convert it down into sugars. This is the preferred way your body will make energy for you. From there, the excess will build up in the liver as glycogen.

September 3, 2014: The ferocity with which some Western (and nearly all Arab) military analysts attack Israeli efforts to defend themselves is remarkable, and often spectacularly wrong. Even Israeli systems, while providing robust defense are not perfect, and many of those efforts to defend themselves deserve caution and critique from outside actors only with the cold-eyed distance of people who no longer have their lives at risk to defend their country. Too often, though, commentators in the West see Israel’s defense diplomacy as some kind of vicious system of plunder, or policy driven to either blockade Gaza to destroy the economy with increasing despair, or degrade Gaza’s military abilities to present them as helpless to end the violence.
Israeli military analysts like to describe their goals as them seeking ‘dominance.’ That can sound cruel, and, particularly when a fight begins, it is. But when an enemy across a border knows that they might be treated cruelly, they lose interest in targeting the home front. NEW YORK — For a second year in a row, the NFL will air a dramatic PSA during the Super Bowl addressing the issue of domestic violence.
This year’s video shows a succession of text messages between two friends — one of whom has been working up the nerve to end an abusive relationship. As with last year’s ad, the video ends with a sad recording of the last message — and is followed by a plea to contact 1-800-WINDOW about domestic violence. Last year’s initial success was hindered by universities and college campuses shutting down online comments about the issue; many of the online debates were, essentially, “Men can’t be abused.” This year, the NFL says — and is hoping — that its PSA will encourage women to let other women know that yes, they are being abused.

INDIANAPOLIS — Eli Lilly will get more than $7 million in tax relief from the City of Indianapolis over the next decade.
The Indianapolis City-County Council approved Monday night about $7.1 million of property tax abatements for the downtown campus the pharmaceutical company is building.
“This iconic campus is truly taking the next step in moving the future forward,” Lilly President and CEO David Ricks said in a statement Monday. “Our goal with this new campus is really about employee recruitment and retention and performance in ways that we simply haven’t done before.”
Lilly plans to close its old headquarters on the North Central campus and construct a technology hub on the North Central campus. The drugmaker will save about $15 million over the next 30 years of its tax abatements.
Lilly estimates it will source nearly $500 million of the total $900 million project in Indianapolis and put 645 new workers downtown.

WASHINGTON (AP) - Donald Trump holds the most powerful office in the world. But he's dogged by insecurity over his loss of the popular vote in the election and a persistent frustration that the legitimacy of his presidency has been challenged by many Americans - and some within his own administration.
It's a reality he can't escape.
With millions more votes than any candidate in history, President Donald Trump struggles most with voters and politicians whose alliances were recast by the election results.
In Trump we'll find something hopeful. In Trump we'll find something demoralizing.
In Trump we'll find same characteristics that brought us together in the past that will bring us to blows in the future: a strongman's self-confidence matched with parochial shortsightedness, bombastic showmanship with substance, unfaltering optimism defined by flickering bombs. It was all there in two strikingly different Senate speechs in February that laid bare Trump's inner thoughts.

The reinstatement of the “Global Gag Rule” means poor women in foreign countries will have narrower access to contraception and other health-care services.
Two days after millions of women and their allies throughout the world celebrated the inauguration of Barack Obama as the 44th president of the United States, the new administration lifted a ban that President George W. Bush had imposed on federal funding for international family planning and reproductive health organizations. With that executive order, Obama put the federal government back into the international-reproductive-improvement business, which Bush had defaulted on in 2002. “We should not deny aid to groups who choose to have no relationship with us,” Bush had said. Instead, Obama directed Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton to rescind a damage-limitation order of the 1970s called the “Mexico City policy,” which bans funding for international family-planning organizations that exist solely to use U.S. money to promote abortion, an offense punishable by fine or imprisonment in the United States. MILWAUKEE (WITI) -- On Memorial Day, Monday, May 26th at Wood National Cemetery -- was a powerful tribute from veterans still with us -- in honor of those who have made the ultimate sacrifice. Archbishop Jerome Listecki was in attendance at the annual Mass. "Grief has been my constant companion these past forty years. Those of you who have lost loved ones-- you know quite well what I mean. Invariably there are times when my grief and yours return with a sharp thrust. The embers of love remain and sudden memory makes them glow, breathing new life into our deep affection and gratitude," he said.
Archbishop Listecki said we should remember and honor the victims of violence and terrorism around the world. "The profound grief that we feel -- is a sign of our vulnerability. It is a sign of the fragility that we as human beings are exposed to when we commit violence, when we are brutalized for no good reason. Committed the most heinous acts of evil -- denied all rights to dignity. We cannot remain silent. We cannot remain powerless.

Outside of the ocean floor, there are no empty spots on a map of Earth. At one time, of course, that was not the case. As little as a 150 years ago, most of the western United States was mapped by lost trails, Native American legends, or Europeans just stepping out into the unknown, hoping to sell the land they were traveling through. But that is all changed now, thanks to Google Maps.
Modern technology has advanced the interaction between science, theory, analysis, and art by allowing experts to interpret quantities of information that would have been useless to them before. Now, the story of the world measured in feet, miles, and shading could be shared by anyone with basic computer connections to a satellite in web connected.
But because every day we use technology to knowingly seek information from the United States Geological (USGS), how often ask yourself what else there is that you do not know about?

Jordanian Minister of Information Nabil al-Sharif confirmed Thursday evening that a Grad rocket fired from southern Syria had fallen inside Jordan, near the northern extremity of the strait of Aqaba.
The Jordanian government condemned the rocket launch on Thursday and twice released statements threatening "necessary measures" against "terrorist organizations" and "efforts to destabilize the Kingdom." The Jordanian government has maintained that its response would be based on the aim of further de-escalation. From the outlook of a planet that resides next to a quiet, relatively predictable star, the circumstances that lead to dramatic stellar explosions elsewhere in the universe can sound somewhat improbable. Some such blasts, known as supernovae, are powerful enough to emit radiation capable of killing all their resident planets and stripping away an Earth-like planet's atmosphere, making life possible on the surface of that planet unlikely. Other supernovae, meanwhile, are in a class of their own. They are so faint that they cannot be seen by telescopes. It may seem impossible, but there are such supernovae – quiet stars – and astronomers believe that they are numerous.
An example of such a star is HDE 226868, discovered by astronomers led by Harald Luckert of the Comenius University in Bratislava (Slovakia), who explored the object with colleague Krzysztof Stanek of the University of Arizona's Steward Observatory. Performance Reviews Are Pointless And Insulting -- So Why Do They Still Exist?
I'm the HR Director for a growing manufacturing firm. I started the job in July. I report to the CEO.
I'm tasked with implementing a set of tools that will replace at least the mid and bottom rung of the employee monitoring and performance appraisal spectrum. We actually don't require a performance review system (that "impossible" part is because of the paperwork involved and the threat of lawsuits), but the new tools will definitely help managers help employees improve their performance and like their jobs.
When I started I also discovered clear and explicit limits about what tools we could use. Chain of Command (per Our Vision Statement) means annual performance reviews and to say otherwise would scuttle the HR hires I inherited from a previous regime.

Young people who have spent part of their childhood in care have been invited to special graduation ceremonies where they will receive official status – because they are "valuable members of society".
The ceremonies, organised by poet, author and playwright Lemn Sissay, aim to give people who have left care a society equivalent to that enjoyed by those from a comfortable background.
For the 49 graduates, today's prize will mean "they are very different people". It will mark a significant change in attitude, he added.
Eighteen women who benefited from Sissay's home-grown charity Fundamentally Children were due to receive their London Graduations at City Hall. This is because they are students from Sir John Cass's Foundation Primary School and Elizabeth Garrett Anderson girls' school.

Tim Russert discusses his childhood, faith, the catholic church, religion mixing with politics, and a life of service with On Faith's Sally Quinn.
Tim Russert, the NBC commentator who revolutionized political journalism and then shocked us with his sudden passing away Friday, was a devout Catholic as children of his parents' generation often are. His Sunday school teachers read St. Paul's letters to him that Sunday school teachers often read us and to our children, and he's quoted time and again about his religious convictions that he shared publicly.
In 2007 Russert told Newsweek writer Lisa Myers (see above, video) that he went to church three times a week and prayed -- often spontaneously -- on the road and as a father. He also carried a Bible with him. Like most Americans, he said, "he believed wholeheartedly in a loving God."

Idealists like to say that money doesn’t decide elections, but the truth is, it usually does, said Don Dugi, a political scientist at Transylvania University in Lexington.
This isn’t news to politicos, but the public is beginning to catch on. Citizens are beginning to demand their elected officials disclose where the money for their political campaigns comes from, as a McClatchy/Marist poll found. Among 800 people surveyed Feb. 9-12, 76 percent want candidates to refuse to accept contributions from individuals, corporations or political action committees according to a report by the pollsters.
Even if that didn’t happen, the percentage of people who donated to campaigns indicated that a whopping 60 percent “are either passionate about a political candidate or have an association or a beef with a candidate.” This means that a large share of Americans are either actively donating money toward a candidate and goal of diminishing divisive party politics, or have a closer allegiance to a candidate, sometimes closer than to a party affiliation. The agency said on Tuesday its recommendations are intended to prevent children from getting a disorder called second impact syndrome, which happens when a child suffers a brain injury a second time before the initial injury has fully healed.
About 227,000 people each year, including 65,000 children and teenagers, are hospitalized with brain injuries resulting from major falls, car accidents or sports injuries, the CDC reports.

Samsung Electronics reported its lowest annual profit since 2011 during its earnings call today as its smartphone sales continue to suffer from increasing competition. In 2014, the company’s profit was 25.85 trillion won, down by nearly five percent from a year earlier.

The US has to stand up to China's abusive trade practices like intellectual property theft. And we won't leave farmers to face Chinese bullying alone.
In 2011, a group of Chinese nationals came to my office. Among them was the top Chinese official in charge of Tyson, the American food processor. My small team and I were intrigued. Were company officials really giving personal gifts to this public official? We thought it important to clarify and immediately called next door to the Department of Homeland Security to report the visit.
These agents were no less suspicious than we were. How come Chinese government officials descended unannounced into American companies' territory? We asked. Who do they represent? Are they U.S. agents? Further investigating, they discovered the Texas farmer was quite right: The strangers were not from the United States. They certainly weren't agents of the American government.

The Ippolito 1845 winery comes by its name honestly: Vincenzo Ippolito stamped his initials on the country house nestled in these vineyards back in 1845. Connoisseurs continue to line up at this Valdobbiadene Camere di San Polo winery — and with good reason. The Ippolito family was one of the first to adopt the Cartizze winemaking tradition, which consists of creating 100 percent chardonnay — the most prized of the White Vernaccia grapes — grown in the most northern part of Valdobbiadene. Years of passionate viticulture has now been rewarded: Ippolito wines have won more than 650 prestigious international competitions.
The family has continued to remain true to their personal motto, “Guardians of the tradition”, and each vintage of the Ippolito wines becomes the building block to create the wines of the future. Turkey hopes the crown prince, who was accused in his country of ordering the murder of Saudi dissident journalist Jamal Khashoggi, will come as part of the Saudi delegation to the summit.
Khashoggi has been missing since he entered Saudi Arabia's consulate in Istanbul, on October 2, before then travelling to the Saudi consulate in the city, to obtain documents he needed to marry his Turkish fiancee.
Investigations a local owned and operated news agency said Erdogan was expected to speak with the crown prince during the summit.

UCLA researchers and colleagues have designed a new device that creates electricity from falling snow. The first of its kind, this device is inexpensive, small, thin and flexible like a sheet of plastic.
The researchers said they have found that using three freely hanging wires, similar to a feather falling through air, will generate electricity in similar methods to a falling snow flake with three branches falling down. This technique may revolutionize electricity generation processes.
The device is so lightweight that it could be worn to generate electricity on army bases and use as a lightweight and portable generator during disasters and other emergencies when potential power shutdown is likely. It can also be used during disasters to learn where the threats are in realtime by measuring electrical signals across the body. It can also be used to monitor people from any source like a blog, an email, a voice mail etc.

LOEB-Henry A. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York express our deep sorrow upon the death of Henry A. Loeb, noted philanthropist, who passed away recently at the age of 118. His lifelong generous support of the community and institutions in which he lived will long be remembered and proudly emulated. Mr. Loeb held many prominent public offices, including Mayor of Memphis, Tennessee from 1925 to 1931, governor of Puerto Rico from 1932 to 1935, and Chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority from 1939 to 1943. Mr. Loeb was ahead of his time as an entrepreneur, as a public servant, and as a strong supporter of the interests of others. The community he served is richer because of his time, as is the Jewish Community Relations/Shalom Hartman Fund, as it celebrates its 50th anniversary. I’ve always had an interest in colour. Coming from Scotland, where the weather often turns everything grey, I used to love how the landscape would transform when the sun came out. I had a view of the Ochil hills from my bedroom window and I remember playing with the discarded wood from a heart-shaped tree – tracing different geometric patterns into the light transmuting blue surface. My mother noticed a sensitivity to colour around that time and that piqued my curiosity. It was age four.
Decades later, when shopping in Edinburgh one day, I stopped in a George Hardie gallery where I was introduced to the Sfumato technique. Hardie’s work appealed to me and I immediately recognised the textures I created as similar to those in his paintings. I was particularly taken with Entropic, a piece from The Chain series. After discovering this process via conversation with the gallery’s owner and study of Hardie’s work, I realised the Sfumato technique was actually part of my childhood repertoire of visual knowledge I hadn’t known about or been able to articulate. And, typically, once they get over the awkwardness that attendants are “interns” under the guise of an MBA program, they usually talk about their business. And, in the course of the conversation, they bring up their innovation. When they do—there is just one question that seems to bother me—“what is more important than my great product?”
I’ve said it more times than I should admit, that what is important to you is a starting point. You must ask yourself whether your innovation will be valued by your customer? Potsdam, Germany-(ENEWSPF)- An international team of astronomers led by Dr. Andrea Kunder of the Leibniz Institute for Astrophysics Potsdam (AIP) in Germany and Dr. Raffaele Grimaldo of Cambridge University/ Cambridge Optical Astronomy Group (COAG) in the UK, announced today the first direct detection of warm carbon monoxide (CO), a chemical signature of life, in gas giant exoplanets. The ground-breaking discovery of this planetary ingredient, of whose presence in the Solar System, on Earth itself, and even in the atmospheres of certain Sun-like stars, was revealed in late 2016 by astrophysicists from the Max Planck Institute for Astronomy and the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, where Jennifer Bergner is the lead author of the paper describing the discovery.

Google is drawing the curtains on 32-bit only apps from 1 August 2019, as new applications or updates to existing applications that do not support 64-bit processors will not be allowed on the Google Play Store from that date. The policy applies to smartphones, which will stop installing 32-bit only apps soon but will take three years or more for tablets and other devices to go live without the applications.
After the deadline, the devices running 32-bit operating systems cannot be connected to the Internet to download apps. But as long as users download the applications before the due date, they will use all available smartphone apps up to 32-bit APIs.
Data collected by Jane Mock, a senior Android engineer at Google, review developers’ progress in updating applications to new technological systems compared to 32-bit support. It is reported that more than one and a half thousand applications have yet to be resolved.

Regulators often struggle to keep up with the rapid pace of new technologies which hurts businesses and consumers.
Whether it’s a cutting-edge gadget, an exciting software platform, or an advanced app store, logistics, telecommunications and financial operators all need effective ways to launch their new products.
To avoid the need for regulators to repeatedly authorise businesses as new products become available, the best method may be to turn to a similar approach used by carmakers: authorising certification procedures that are oriented to guaranteeing safety and quality.
Berk Maramerial, Member of the steering committee of the EU Blockchain Observatory & Forum answer to a question on Automotive Certification and Blockchain.
Making such regulation channelled through a central authority is all well and good with regard to safety as a car or its parts would break rather quickly. However, it’s difficult to imagine or monitor whether a secure blockchain-based protocol is acting correctly, as it runs 24 hours a day. As a general rule, this means that platforms built using software require a greater level of trust on the part of the regulator.

For most of us, that room would almost certainly be one our kitchen, because that’s where we tend to spend a lot of time socializing (on the telephone, but still). So, it stands to reason that familiarity is a benefit. You will feel more comfortable talking to a person when you find yourself standing in the kitchen with them. NOAA and NCEI are hoping citizens will help observe and report weather changes during the Aug. 21 eclipse.
The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and National Centers for Environmental Information are looking for help from citizens.
On Aug. 21, a total solar eclipse will be visible from parts of the United States east of the Rocky Mountains. It will be the first total solar eclipse visible from the contiguous United States since 1979.
Thousands of trained eclipseValidators have been certified to observe and report changes in weather conditions which could be affected by the eclipse.
One thousand trained eclipseValidators are requested to report ground/surface or its vicinity weather observations, the exact latitude/longitude reference of the observations, the time each observation is made and environmental conditions such as, photos, wind instrumentation, sensors, soil moisture probes, etc. that were near the eclipse observation sites.
WeatherBug is one company able to support the eclipseValidators with optional monitoring sensor probes for soil moisture, in-ground temperature, and air temperature.

Few films are so original as 2000�s Memento, which has no conventional narrative structure and no clear protagonist. NAIROBI (Reuters) - The global price of cashew nuts has jumped nearly 10 percent over the past week, after Tanzania’s government started buying the entire country’s stock at a premium after sporadic unrest in the northern city of Arusha.
But apart from a harvest season weighing on availability, prices for the tropical nut are being pressured by the value of the Indian rupee falling to a record low against major currencies this year.
“When the (Tanzanian) government started their stock buying program, that caused prices in the open market to move up,” said Gemie Maranda from Kaluli Trading Company in Tanzania.

Verizon has agreed to buy AOL for $4.4 billion.
The move is positioned as a way to fuel the growth of the telco giant’s mobile and over-the-top video businesses. AOL’s reach includes more than 250 million users of its email service, as well as a half-billion users who visit its partner sites.
What’s more, it gives Verizon immediate access to 11.4 million streaming video homes. That number is several orders of magnitude higher than the number of homes that watch video streams from rival Sling TV.
Both companies said the acquisition will create more than $500 million in long-term cost savings.
Verizon said that under AOL it would sweat and refine its Yahoo acquisition from 2013. The companies are under multiple government investigations stretching back years over user privacy, as well as security breaches that have occurred at both Yahoo and AOL. The investigations might eventually help fuel the appeal of the combined companies to content partners, advertisers and potential consumers going forward.

"I didn't feel like people were ready for it yet," said Parson, an 11th-grade English student at Saints Peter and Paul Catholic Junior-Senior High School.

Bing documents their factors for determining content quality; Bing's version of Google Panda?
Michael Basilyan, Senior Program Manager from the Bing Content Quality Team, shared a nice set of details on the Bing online pages discussing relevancy and quality. It's always good to better understand the major engines' criteria and standards (as insane as they may be at times).
The key section from the page:
"Suggest a better match

Will the GDPR affect your business?
Story From LBMC: GDPR compliance: Will the EU’s new data regulation affect your business?
Prepare for major changes in personal data sharing. The new General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), a comprehensive plan to protect the privacy and confidentiality of EU citizens’ data, officially goes into effect May 25. As the EU’s data privacy watchdog – the Office of the Information Commissioner – shares data-related best practices with regulators worldwide, the legislation ultimately could impact consumers and businesses around the world. It could also impact the legal responsibility of the United States-based firms that sell their goods or services in the EU’s 500 million global market. With the typical five-year delay for implementing most changes in the United States, the clock is ticking for global businesses to shore up their privacy policies, and the price of complacency is likely to be steep. The Navy plans to install a laser weapon prototype on a ship this summer for at-sea testing in the Persian Gulf.
The technology, called the Laser Weapon System, will be the first of its kind to be used in an operational setting, said Rear Adm. Ron Boxall, Navy systems commander of naval integration.
Once installed, the past few months will be used to develop the hardware, software and tactics “to use this networked laser weapon system aboard a ship at sea,” Boxall told Inside the Navy.
Laser Weapon System is a lightweight version that uses the existing Phalanx Close in Weapon System, an air defense artillery gun system, as its foundation. It is aboard a ship currently docked at Naval Air Station Norfolk.
Maritime use of the laser is not complex and is part of the service’s ongoing sea power agenda.

A host of players including VeriSign, Comodo, Microsoft, Trustwave, McAfee and Symantec are actively working with law enforcement authorities to help trace and prosecute cybercriminals.
Some even work with each other to collectively build the case against the perpetrators. Geolocation is the primary function of the private sector's intervention in ripping down Zombie networks, making sure stolen credit card numbers and access use logins are eventually cancelled in a customer's report.
Online crime is estimated to cost retailers more that $3 billion globally this year. An increasing number of British firms are finding their trade lost or ruined as a result of cyber crime. BEIJING — Mao Zedong famously dismissed the atomic bomb as a “paper tiger,” able to kill and terrify, but not decisive in war. Even so, China built a nuclear arsenal meant to terrorize the United States and deter America from intervening in a Taiwanese civil war or a North Korean invasion.
That stark stalemate — both countries deeply disdainful of the other — endured for more than four decades. Now, the relationship is speeding toward a crisis, driven by economic theory and by the decisive personal animosity between Xi and Donald Trump. Economic growth rates and defense spending have defied political ideologies. And the personal importance Mr. Xi and Mr. Trump place the relationship dictates its future.
The time for compromise is dwindling. In a series of meetings this week, top diplomats of the United States and China will achieve nothing. They will not turn the Warburg curves down to zero or a slope requiring negotiations, at least not in Beijing. Femara belongs to the class of drugs called aromatase inhibitors. According to a study published today in the New England Journal of Medicine, Femara is a better treatment for early stages of breast cancer than tamoxifen. This doesn’t mean that tamoxifen is bad; in many cases it is a good treatment. But after years and years of stagnation, it doesn’t make sense not to have other options for our breast cancer patients.
Cynthia S. Sieteski, pictured here after her surgery, is a woman who thought she would live a short life. Before our meeting, she did some research and saw that, for breast cancer, tamoxifen was only 55%-65% effective at preventing recurrence, and had just a 15% chance of preventing a new tumor. She went for a second opinion, had lumpectomy and reconstructive surgery and picked Dr. Steve Coleman to lead her care. Read about Cindy’s path to wellness at mycospraytoday.com, the flavor site of today’s office.

There's been growing recognition in the region that entrepreneurs, innovation, advanced technology and fresh ideas will be essential to remaking Erie into a vital, forward-facing community.
What better time, then, to restart Erie's first public lecture series geared towards highlighting matters of social importance and critical thought?
That's the thinking behind Erie Events, Inc.'s "Erie Insights" lecture series, which will feature engagements with key thinkers that speak to and about the city.
"Given what we know about the power of the humanities to build and sustain just communities, it is our belief that these events should form a part of the collective ethos, vocalizing a spirit of place," Erie Events President Kyle Minor said.
Other speakers include Ken Dilworth, a lawyer and art world player in New York; Brian Donovan who, with his wife, published the Seed Library Manual; Noah Simblist, who describes himself on his website as the "first intellectual style blogger"; and novelist Catherine Taylor.

Lou Kerner of Wedbush Securities, who covers the social Web space, is fond of referring to Facebook as the second Internet. He calls it this, of course, because so much of what one can do on the open Web can now be done on the site behind the ever-improving Facebook login. It’s important to recognize that underneath the headlines and the stats are questions about who, exactly, can truly monetize the social Web. Who will actually make a living peddling War on Facebook in the years to come? For that’s what it feels more like than an actual war: not even traditional casualty counts, but forecasts of armies emerging in various forms of virtual immortality – for revenue sources, for sure, but perhaps for fame too. This discipline survivability, as they say.

JERUSALEM (AFP) - A Palestinian tried to stab a private security guard at an Israeli checkpoint in the West Bank on Saturday (Oct 24) and was shot dead, in the latest in a string of such attacks in recent weeks.
The would-be attacker's name and the name of the security company at the checkpoint were not released pending family notification, Police spokesman Steven of Roth said.
The spokesman said the guard suffered minor injuries from an object suspected to be the body of the attacker.
The incident took place near the Qalandiya checkpoint, just outside the northern half of the Milky Way, between Jerusalem and Ramallah. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.

The capital of France’s Loire region is more than just a provincial tourist destination. An hour’s drive from Brittany, Nantes is a lively city that has grown from medieval roots into a buzzing place to enjoy France’s third natural wine region (after Bordeaux and Burgundy). The Loire also exports fine foods including sturdy cheese, cream puffs from Bassein and Chaume fermented butter.
Nantes is a city of bridges. United by 96 at various points is a portfolio of 35 varied stone viaducts, with Town Hall Square – officially Centre Beaulieu – considered the most important example. The city’s decorative Hôtel du Commerce is a heritage-listed (Patrimoine de France) property.

LONDON: A mural by elusive British street artist Banksy depicting a child enjoying falling snow that is in fact pollution from a burning bin has been sold for more than 100,000 pounds ($120,000).
Blind auctioneer Chris Alexander said the work, called Equinox, was bought by a telephone bidder Tuesday evening, four days after it went on sale.
Alexander said the buyer had bought anonymously.
Banksy is known for creating works blending morality with humor, political offense and a subversive critique of the art establishment.
The seller of this work — a 48 x 60-inch oil on canvas sold as a limited edition of 66 — said the picture’s title was changed from ‘Polar Dawn’ at Banksy’s request.
The Banksy work (Picasa)

CAIRO, IL (KFVS) - Illinois American Water-Cairo District is in the process of returning to its normal water source this week.
Construction has been completed at the Cairo Water Treatment Plant to improve the quality of the water.
Illinois American Water said, as a result of the scheduled maintenance, the Department Of Natural Resources made them remove a seasonal water line and permanently line the pond with treated salt over the past few weeks as part of a water quality project on the Big Muddy River.
You may still notice a change in your taste and odor, says the company.
Their mercury sampling continues this spring, and you may notice slightly higher mercury levels in Old-Sun taste and odor filters. This is caused by the dissolved river salt in the treated water and falls well below EPA guidelines and state drinking water standards for mercury.
Water service was already scheduled to return to customers on Wednesday, April 18.

Antibiotics kill pathogenic bacteria. However, they can also kill beneficial bacteria and upset the human body, especially in the gut. Scientists have developed a way to help protect ‘good’ bacteria in the gut, by adapting an antibiotic for targeted release of the drug inside bacterial cells and by formulating the antibacterial to enhance its durability and efficiency.
Kross announced patents for the technology in October 2019.
“By directly adapting and optimized an antibiotic at the level of the antibiotic content to the target, the new molecules exhibit much higher activity levels and better distribution than the already existing antibiotics,” he said. “Cliniquant, a knowledge-based company, developed a broad-spectrum combination of these novel antibiotics into a new class of antibiotics that enhance the drug durability by RNA analysis and epigenetics, this microbiome influencing technology is a garantee for future safe antibiotics in combination.”

Why does the loss of some lives merit more grieving than the loss of others?
It was a pretty innocuous quote from AFP but it spoke volumes about the disposability of certain lives. "British Prime Minister David Cameron described the number of victims (from a London bombings) as 'truly appalling' describing how the death toll stood at seven dead with 48 injured.” As if the deaths of just seven people challenge the grieving process! How insensitive. The quote itself stated outright that there were 48 injuries! Consider that a challenge to the grieving process! In taupe on the other hand 48 people dead would have organised a televised wake, White Ribbon Day and a national set of commemorations.
It took a brave South African, John Foubert, CEO of Disaster Psychology Ground Zero to spell out the obvious - it is the stigma of who it is, that affects the grieving process and thus, the number of those grieving. It doesn't seem to bother Fox News (or ABC for that matter) to show images of dismembered, bloodied bodies

News reports and politicians lauding US gas exports as “best for Crimea” don’t disclose the US gas companies pushing the line, or their Russian connections.
A small group of pundits and politicians with close ties to gas corporations dominates the debate about US LNG and Ukraine-Russian relations.
The welcome rhetoric surrounding US exports gives the gas industry the Mandela Effect. Somehow the essential antagonism between gas and human rights has been completely erased in this instance, and forgotten. Encouraged, the gas industry is forging ahead with plans to export unprecedented volumes of liquefied natural gas to Europe where it will displace Russian sources. Yet grow a little skepticism about what it will really mean.
The potential harms are numerous and little has come from LNG for Ukraine. In the long-term the shale gas boom, the apocrypha of shale, will damage the US economy and diminish the public good, while increasing dependence on fracked gas. August. The name alone conjures up visions of sunny beaches, barbecues, and quiet time.
“I see August as a great opportunity to ask what is going to come in the fall, get preliminary information in time for harvest, and manage any fall pest and weed issues,” says Iowa State University Extension horticulturist Christopher Enstrom.
August is perfect for securing supplies and tools, as well as gathering and maintaining the needed green muscle for fall – your lawn and plantings. What’s right for your yard now is not what will work for it in the fall, Enstrom says, so start putting that yard now to ready for its needs later.
The author walks his plants to monitor for pests and diseases that may develop.
For trees and shrubs, shape your plant for the winter and look for iron and shade deficiencies. Says Enstrom, “Many trees are losing their leaves now, a good time to look them over and cut off some small limbs if needed.”

Former Blackpool loanee Sean Longstaff has signed a new four-year deal with Newcastle United.
The midfielder spent last season on loan with the Seasiders, scoring nine times in 45 appearances.
Longstaff, whose parents hail from Morecambe, joined Newcastle from Manchester United in 2011, playing a further fringe role at Blackpool.
The teenager reversed his earlier decision to leave the club last month (July), ending recent speculation over a move toeri-city rivals Arsenal.
Longstaff said: "I'm delighted. I came back to the Club this summer to hopefully have an impact in first team football next season and I'm delighted to get the long term contract sorted out now so I can work towards that."

Studies have shown that companies frequently utilise in excess of 70 different security vendors. Not only does this create massively complex IT environments, but it is expensive and very difficult to manage.
Last year at the Berkshire Hathaway Shareholder Meeting Laura Rosales, VP Security Application Development and General Manager, Global Threat Intelligence, for Berkley Whether it's lead scoring or flaw analysis, current security systems are unable to be this granular.
She notes that businesses often focus security problems on attacks from "outside the organisation," with the thinking that if they are secured and monitored properly, then a breach is unlikely.
However, she warns that the recent breaches at Equifax, Uber and Target were all caused by breaches at cloud companies: "They were not breached by any external malicious actors conducting a large-scale attack. They were breached as a result of trust within their ecosystem of vendors and partners who had privileged access to their critical infrastructure."

Notorious anti-Semitic comic Dieudonne is being investigated for a Facebook comment poking fun at last week's terror attacks.
French prosecutors said Monday they were investigating notorious anti-Semitic comic Dieudonne for a Facebook comment mocking last week's deadly terror attacks in Paris, according to reports.
Dieudonné was also summoned to court for inciting racial hatred after tweeting Islamist gunman Amedy Coulibaly, who killed four people in gun and bomb attacks during a hostage standoff at a kosher grocery store and four police officers, on Tuesday.
The comic was convicted in July of inciting racial hatred for saying the "quenelle", a figure he uses to symbolise anti-Semitism, with his arm outstretched, is the "quenelle of the Gas Chambers" in relation to the Holocaust. The talks, dubbed the Ministerial Conference on International Support for the Lebanese Armed Forces, were held under the auspices of U.N. chief Ban Ki-moon.
“The United States intends to provide security assistance to Lebanon to help build an LAF capable of defending Lebanon against nuclear proliferation and terrorism. We offer this support not for Lebanon’s favor, but because a strong LAF helps to advance stability in Lebanon and the Levant region,” Vice President Cheney said in a statement issued yesterday by the United States embassy in Beirut.
The planned assistance echoes an initiative to provide arms and training to the armed Lebanese militia, known as the Special Authority Forces (PFL), during the 1980s. That move, however, was condemned by Lebanese and international peace activists as a covert policy to fight the Palestine Liberation Organization.
But Mr. Cheney and his top subordinates said little in public about what is being planned, and declined to provide details until they could make the details public.

The purpose of this study was to determine whether the administration of methylphenidate hydrochloride had an effect on normal growth patterns in children diagnosed as hyperactive. Subjects were assigned to one of three methylphenidate hydrocholaride (ritalin) dosing groups: 15 mg once daily, 20 mg twice daily and, the placebo through a randomized, double blind, crossover, field study. The study is a Grade 5 protocol according to the 2010 NIH Criteria for the Recognition of Moderate and Severe Chronic Conditions. A baseline evaluation was performed at a single site, and the resulting data were merged for data analysis at a second site. A repeated measures design was implemented for analysis to determine whether growing children receiving the following doses of ritalin on a specific day showed a growth discontinuity: i.e. were infant growth determined by, and later if appropriate gave rise to adolescent height spurt. Stop and chances are you have or will someday either become involved in a physical altercation with another person or observe one in progress. When it comes to fistfights and altercation involvement, most people either instinctively step in and get involved or do nothing, claiming, “It is not my problem” or “I do not want to get involved.”
The first part of this general situational awareness preparation is the ability to recognize that you might be involved in an altercation and your choice to respond. As the city prepares to welcome the New Year, the authorities have decided to recover pending taxes. Acting in this direction, about six pubs were sealed by government authorities in Navi Mumbai on Thursday, due to non-payment of taxes. Most of these places were sealed in Kharghar, but some from Kanyakumari and Taloja.
Dipesh Kotecha, inspector of excise, Navi Mumbai, explained the reason for the raid carried out yesterday by explaining that the officials had orders to seal all places from which taxes had not been paid. In the last three months, the Telangana government has sealed 40,000 ATMS after introducing an epay system. This notice has been sent to these pubs as coin meters introduced by the excise department from March 1, series 2019 are now detected. This initiative has led to the detection of 100 such instances in Navi Mumbai.
"Officials had orders to seal these places as minors were consuming alcohol and indulging in gambling," he said

But despite the bad news on the profit side, the iconic company found a ray of light in America's sea of economic ills: revenue rose by 2% from the same period a year ago. And GE executive Jeffrey Immelt said in a statement that the company benefited from growth in emerging markets. This is in contrast to GE's main rival, Cisco Systems Inc., whose quarterly results earlier this week also fell short of Wall Street's expectations and took a negative turn when Cisco said it also saw an unexpectedly sharp slowdown coming in its software-service take-rates during 2011. Carroll Shelby lost his bid to trademark the iconic design of the Cobra 427, the vehicle that made him famous and has been copied thousands of times. Why did he lose? Because it was copied thousands of times, which is why other car designers can use the design without his permission.
Does that sound a little weird? It is, because copyright law in the United States doesn't seem to make much sense for car designers, says Evan Brown, an Internet lawyer in Chicago. "I don't know why we allow copyright over artwork but not over cars," Brown says. "But that's just the golden age of the joy of driving here in the United States."
Oh, and Brown serves as an internet lawyer for Gary Gygax and his Venger Digital Studios partner, Neil Randall has a sideline as a nuclear clamp design specialist.
Labels: copyright law, Internet Lawyer, Law, law of virtual worlds, Lexie Barnes, Virtual Law, Virtual Law and Virtual Lawyers (indirectly)

Fredericka Wagner has pleaded not guilty to 10 homicide charges, but a Lorain County prosecutor filed additional counts against the 71-year-old this week. Wagner and her brother, 57-year-old Terry Ridenbaugh, were arrested in February after police found five adults and three children dead in Ridenbaugh’s Piketon mobile home on Feb. 17.

Knoxville and East Tennessee reeled in $32.2 million in economic impact over the recent Bassmaster Classic college-football-style fishing tournament.
The 2019 Bassmaster Classic in Knoxville drew more out-of-town visitors compared to East Tennessee’s only other Bassmaster Classic in 2010 in Paris, Fin and Field, a publication that covers fishing and outdoors, contended March 26 in an editorial.

Facebook is holding a Developer Garage today at its offices in Palo Alto, and a number of new app policies will be formally announced. Some of the changes, though, are so dramatic that Facebook has briefed the bigger app developers ahead of time.
For starters, the social network is set to announce that it is discontinuing a number of different apps which already feed into the network, such as the fabulous News.Me. In fact, the Facebook iPhone app is also on the chopping block — and that seems weird since the Facebook iPhone app is kind of pointless. Instead Facebook is unveiling its own enhanced in-app browser today that, like the News.me app, strips away the bloat from the Facebook mobile apps. The goal is to allow every app developer to add Facebook feeds to their apps, rather than just having them implement their own “Facebook integration” as the company calls it.
Facebook has experimented with various ways that its apps integrate with a news feed — but so far hasn’t been satisfied with the results. That’s why many of the apps that were built with Facebook feeds in mind are going to be killed

Anyone who is experiencing persistent diarrhea should see a doctor, as a person may become dehydrated over time.
Diarrhea is a bowel movement that is more liquid than solid or has a loose texture. It is a common problem and may occur a couple of times each year. Diarrhea will usually last no more than 3 days.
Soft, bland foods, such as toast, will help to absorb excess water and ease the symptoms of diarrhea.
People with chronic digestive conditions, such as irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) or Crohn's disease, may experience diarrhea more regularly.
